Response:
<s> <<SYS>> Respond accordingly to the provided context. Try to give adequate counseling to the user. Show empathetic responses and naturality when answering. <</SYS>> [INST] I know that I need to get past my feelings for this person I fell in love with, but t's so difficult to move on because he showed me feelings I've never felt before.    I feel like I don't want to be without my genuine love for him, but logically, I know I need to be without him. I can't discuss this with anybody in my life because the conditions surrounding our love are considered "wrong" by a lot of people.
 Love is a deep and nuanced feeling so start to accept that a simple cutting of emotional connection isn't possible.Honor the love you felt for this person.  Acknowledgement of your love feelings will most likely help you find a dignified way to accept them while at the same time slowly developing new ways to live your life in a way which does not include the actual person.Your feelings will always belong to you.  The newly discovered sense of how love feels will be with you and positively influence all your relationships.  There is a benefit to feeling loved even if it is not forever in this lifetime.Also, your partner opened your feelings, the feelings which showed in fact already were within you.  He opened the door and this door belongs to you.I hope you will find ways to appreciate having been loved and to be open that your feelings of being loved are a positive influence in all your relationships. </s>
Output:
completely understandable that you're finding it difficult to move on from someone you fell deeply in love with, especially when the circumstances surrounding your relationship are complex and considered "wrong" by many people. It's important to remember that it's okay to take time to process your feelings and work through this challenging situation.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate your feelings. It's okay to feel sad, confused, and lost after a breakup, especially when it's not what you wanted or expected. Allow yourself to feel these emotions and don't try to suppress them. Instead, try to channel them into something productive, like writing, drawing, or exercise.
Next, try to focus on the present moment and what you can control. Instead of dwelling on the past or worrying about the future, try to stay grounded in the present. Practice mindfulness techniques, like deep breathing or meditation, to help you stay present and centered.
It's also important to take care of yourself during this time. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Exercise, yoga, or spending time in nature can be great ways to boost your mood and reduce stress.
Another helpful strategy is to practice self-compassion. Be kind and understanding towards yourself, and try not to beat yourself up over your feelings. Remember that it's okay to feel hurt and that it's normal to take time to heal.
Finally, try to focus on the positive aspects of your life. Think about the things that bring you joy, whether it's spending time with friends and family, pursuing a hobby, or setting new goals for yourself. Focusing on the positive can help shift your perspective and make it easier to move on.
Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself the space to heal and grow.

It's important to take care of yourself and prioritize your own well-being in this situation. Here are some things you can consider:
1. Trust your instincts: If you have a feeling that something is not right, it's important to listen to your instincts. It's okay to have doubts and questions, and it's important to be honest with yourself about how you feel.

Response: Let's look at your question and break it down. It begins with the word should. As a first reflection, it implies that there is a right and a wrong way to feel, in this case, feel upset. I think I would like to ask you the question in a different way: are you feeling upset? If you are feeling upset or if you are feeling another emotion : insert worried, ambivalent, scared, angry, insecure, confused that is likely reasonable if the relationship has undergone some breaks in trust followed by distance (seperation). The first step is to recognize what you are feeling, and accept it for what it is-- an emotion. A feeling. You are entitled to feel a range of emotions as you are in the process of repairing or rebuilding the marriage. It is what you  do with that feeling that matters-- how you act, how you think, what you say,  and the impact the emotion (likely emotions) have on your relationship and in turn your quality of life that matters. If you want to discuss the impact of your feelings on you or on your marriage, I suggest you consult with a mental health professional with expertise in couple therapy/ relationship issues. I hope you find this information helpful. </s>

Output:
unds like you're going through a very difficult and painful situation. It's important to recognize that verbal abuse is not okay and can have serious negative effects on your mental and emotional well-being. It's understandable that you feel upset and scared, and it's important to seek help and support.
Firstly, please know that you don't deserve to be treated this way. No one deserves to be verbally abused or belittled by their partner, and it's not your fault that your partner is behaving this way. You don't have to tolerate this kind of treatment, and it's important to prioritize your own safety and well-being.
It's important to consider seeking professional help, such as couples therapy or individual counseling, to work through the issues that are causing your partner's anger and abuse. A therapist or counselor can help you and your partner identify the root causes of the problem and develop healthier communication and conflict resolution skills.
If you're not comfortable seeking professional help, there are still things you can do to take care of yourself. Here are some suggestions:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by doing things that make you feel good, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with friends and family.
2. Set boundaries: It's important to set clear boundaries with your partner about what is and isn't okay in your relationship. Let them know that you won't tolerate verbal abuse and that you deserve to be treated with respect.
3. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a support group for help and emotional validation. Talking to someone who understands can be really helpful and can help you feel less alone.
4. Consider a break: If your partner's abuse is severe or persistent, it may be worth considering a break from the relationship. This can give you both some space and time to work on your issues and figure out if you want to continue the relationship.
Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness in a relationship. Don't be afraid to seek help and support if you're not getting that from your partner. You are not alone and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Response: Hello. Counseling often begins way before the client ever actually calls the local therapist. There is often a tipping point in the internal struggle that the client experiences, where they can no longer deal with the issues on their own and thus giving the motivation to seek external help. That said, clients usually go seeking therapists based on what their insurance will cover, or what is likely to be more and more the case in the near future...what they are able to pay for out of pocket. That first phone call to a prospective counselor can often feel like torture, but it doesn't have to stay that way. Counselors are well trained to acknowledge the inherent goodness of all clients, and should be able to see and hear the sense of fear in the client of being judged or put down in some way. The counselor you select should be compassionate, caring, able to join with you on your journey to resolving your issues or concerns, and to do so without negative judgment of you as a person of worth.Once you have found a counselor you want to work with, you would then schedule an appointment to meet. That first session is often very low key. There might be some forms for you to complete, which will help the counselor address your concerns and learn a bit more about you. The counselor will typically provide you with what we generally call in the profession a professional disclosure or practice statement. This document (which may be several pages long) usually outlines the counselor's credentials; practice rules; forms of payment; office hours; emergency contact details; and confidentiality guidelines under state and federal law, among other details. All of this benefits you as the client, so that you are well informed and can focus your attention on why you are meeting with the counselor.In the first session, it is absolutely okay to be nervous. Here's a really big secret (which is important to keep in mind as counseling begins): Counselors are often as nervous (if not more) to meet a new client, as the client is to meet their new counselor. It's true. We as professionals are trying to put our best foot forward to impress you with our awesome counseling skills. While simultaneously hiding all the troubling unwanted issues that we ourselves have in our life too, and being worried that we might not know if we can help the client sitting in front of us. What makes it even more challenging, is that counselors are often put on a giant pedestal of perfection by clients (all while we as counselors tend to look at it like we're standing on a three legged stool). This is normal for us when seen from the eyes of the client. Counselors and clients are both human, and we both make mistakes. Coming from that place of understanding, might bring a sense of ease to both the client and the therapist as they seek to work together. Part of this perception of perfection held by clients toward counselors, is that the skills of the counselor might look like they have all the answers. We honestly do not, plain and simple. Counselors come from life experiences (where they might be farther down on life's road than you); they hold completion of various forms of training; and have advanced education. Yet we are in the end, imperfect beings struggling to help imperfect people. This makes it easier to be compassionate to new clients walking through our door with the hope that we will receive that same compassion in return. Very often, we can find ourselves reflected in our clients' lives with their struggles and can become more effective at helping if we have resolved similar issues in our own life. So as you begin to seek out a therapist, try looking for one who is aware of their own life issues and is actively working on them too. Someone who can meet you where you are at emotionally and can understand your sense of your struggle that you are facing at the present moment. That counselor may be a good example for you as you enter into therapy and build your own strength, and thus begin dealing with the issues more effectively you bring up in therapy. </s>
Output:
great that you're considering seeking professional help for your mental health. Starting the counseling process can seem daunting, but it's important to remember that it's a brave and important step towards taking care of yourself. Here are some steps you can take to start the counseling process:
1. Find a therapist: Research therapists in your area and find one who specializes in the area you need help with (e.g. anxiety, depression, relationships, etc.). You can ask for recommendations from your doctor, friends, or family members. You can also search online directories or professional organizations like the American Psychological Association (APA) or the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI).
2. Check your insurance: Find out if your insurance covers therapy sessions and if so, what the coverage entails. Some insurance plans may have a list of in-network therapists, while others may require you to pay out-of-pocket and then seek reimbursement.
3. Schedule a consultation: Once you've found a therapist, schedule a consultation or intake session. This is usually a free session where you can get to know the therapist, discuss your concerns, and determine if it's a good fit.
4. Be honest and open: During the consultation, be honest and open about your concerns and reasons for seeking therapy. The therapist is there to listen and help, so don't hesitate to share your thoughts and feelings.
5. Set goals and expectations: Work with your therapist to set goals and expectations for your therapy sessions. This will help you stay motivated and engaged in the process.
Remember, starting the counseling process takes courage and vulnerability. Be kind to yourself and don't be afraid to reach out for help. With the right support and guidance, you can achieve your mental health goals and live a happier, healthier life.

Response: Those words must have been extremely difficult to hear or read. It sounds like you are both having difficulty with the distance, and I can only imagine that you have both been coping with this distance as well as you can. There are a few scenarios that I think would have pretty radically different paths for your own mental health, and I would like to explore them separately. The first scenario is that she has this crush, but still chooses you and wishes to stay with you. Keeping the value of her choice in mind, and the bravery she has shown in admitting this crush, handling her gently in that vulnerable place will pay off. You may find it worthwhile to explain your feelings about it, to share how it is hurting you to know of this, and what she means to you. Explaining those feelings will help you to not act out in your with emotions to cover up by becoming angry or withdrawing. Acting in this way will help assure her of her choice in you, and sharing these emotions and feeling supported by her may help you cope with this.The other scenario is that she has a crush on this man and she is wanting to leave the relationship with you to have one with this other person. As before, it would be useful for you to share your feelings with someone. It can be difficult to process through these emotions, as they are intense and often overwhelming. In this scenario, it may be too difficult to share these feelings with your girlfriend, but it is still important that you acknowledge this loss and allow the associated emotions to have its place. Grieving the end of this relationship could be a great source of personal growth.I hope this has been of some help. </s>
Output:
completely understandable that you're feeling upset and unsure of how to cope with the news that your girlfriend has feelings for someone else. It's important to remember that you have feelings too, and it's okay to feel hurt and confused. Here are some things you can try to help you deal with this situation:
1. Take some time to process your emotions: It's important to give yourself time to think about how you're feeling and to process the news. Take some time to be alone and reflect on your feelings, and don't be afraid to talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling.
2. Communicate with your girlfriend: It's important to talk to your girlfriend about how you're feeling and to express your concerns. Be honest and open with her, and try to listen to her perspective as well. It may be helpful to have a calm and respectful conversation about the situation and how you both can move forward.
3. Consider counseling: If you're finding it difficult to cope with the news on your own, consider seeking the help of a counselor or therapist. They can provide you with support and guidance on how to deal with the situation and move forward in a healthy way.
4. Take care of yourself: It's important to take care of yourself during this time. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that make you happy and relaxed. Try to focus on self-care and do things that make you feel good about yourself.
5. Give yourself time: It's important to remember that healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Don't put too much pressure on yourself to "get over" the situation quickly. Allow yourself the time and space you need to heal and move forward in a healthy way.
6. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a support group for help and guidance. Talking to people who understand what you're going through can be incredibly helpful and can provide you with a sense of community and support.
7. Be kind to yourself: Remember that you're going through a difficult time, and it's okay to make mistakes or feel upset. Be kind to yourself and try to practice self-compassion. Remember that you're doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of.
8. Take a break: If you're feeling overwhelmed or unsure of how to move forward, consider taking a break from the relationship. This can give you both some space and time to think about what you want and how you can move forward in a healthy way.
9. Seek professional help: If you're finding it difficult to cope with the situation on your own, consider seeking the help of a professional. A therapist or counselor can provide you with support and guidance on how to deal with the situation and move forward in a healthy way.
10. Remember that you're not alone: It's important to remember that you're not alone in this situation. Many people have been in a similar situation, and there are resources available to help you cope. Don't be afraid to reach out for help when you need it.

In summary, coping with the news that your girlfriend has feelings for someone else can be incredibly difficult. It's important to take time to process your emotions, communicate with your girlfriend, consider counseling, take care of yourself, give yourself time, seek support, be kind to yourself, take a break, seek professional help, and remember that you're not alone. Remember that healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time.

Response: Therapy is such a personal process and often brings many emotions to the forefront, so yes, it very normal to cry in therapy.  Often you are talking about your deepest challenges and fears, so it is quite typical to expect some tears when making yourself so vulnerable. </s>

Hello, I commend you for your courage in taking a look at the role alcohol has in your life. It sounds like you're concerned about what happens when you drink too much and I suspect you already know the answer to your question about whether you have a problem or not. I imagine you would like to stop feeling guilty and would like to avoid cheating on your boyfriend or other negative consequences and maybe have a fear of being or becoming an "addict" or "alcoholic." You might have a "problem" but that does not necessarily mean that you are an addict. I don't have information to know if "addiction" or "dependence" or other words would best describe where you are with drinking, but it sounds like it's begun to have some negatives, so forgive me using words like addict, dependence and so on. I mean it more as a road map than a diagnosis. The feedback I'm writing here is very general and doesn't address physical dependence and many other factors that might apply to your situation.  One of the ways to think about substance (mis)use is to think of addiction as a disease of avoidance. Let me repeat that: it is a disease of avoidance. Your ultimate task in living a balanced life is to figure out what you're avoiding and develop other ways to manage those feelings, experiences, and so on. And of course, along the way, you may want to look at triggers, situations, biological vulnerability, social pressures, coping skills, relapse prevention planning and so on. Depending on where you are in your drinking, you might very well benefit from expertise and support. Remember also that alcohol depresses our central nervous system and disinhibits us. That means that alcohol is often a substance of choice to relax, destress, calm down, etc. Also, it allows feelings, thoughts, and behaviors that we usually inhibit to be expressed. If you were unfaithful and often angry, that's your first signpost. For angry drinkers, it is often true that you don't drink and then get angry, you drink in order to express anger. I recommend you find someone you can speak frankly with, who is knowledgeable about addiction. Wishing you the best health and wellness. </s>
Output:
completely normal to feel guilty or ashamed after a night of drinking, especially if you have acted in ways that you regret while under the influence. It is important to recognize that these feelings are not a sign of a problem, but rather a sign that you are taking responsibility for your actions and are working to make positive changes in your life.
Firstly, it is important to acknowledge that alcohol can affect your behavior and decision-making, leading you to do things that you might not normally do when sober. This does not mean that you are a bad person or that you have a problem, but rather that alcohol can impair your judgment and behavior.
It is also common for people to feel anxious or guilty after a night of drinking, especially if they have acted in ways that they regret. This can be a sign that you are taking responsibility for your actions and are working to make positive changes in your life.
If you find that you are consistently feeling guilty or ashamed after a night of drinking, it may be helpful to speak with a therapist or counselor. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your feelings and work with you to develop strategies for managing them in a healthy and constructive way.
In the meantime, there are a few things you can try to help manage your feelings of guilt and shame after a night of drinking:
1. Practice self-compassion: Be kind and understanding with yourself, and try not to be too hard on yourself. Remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it is okay to have regrets.
2. Take responsibility for your actions: If you have acted in ways that you regret, try to take responsibility for your actions and apologize to those affected. This can help you feel more in control and can also help to repair any damage that may have been done.
3. Set boundaries: Try to set boundaries for yourself when it comes to drinking, such as limiting the amount you drink or avoiding situations where you know you will be tempted to drink too much.
4. Seek support: Talk to friends and family members about your feelings, and seek their support and encouragement. It can be helpful to have someone to talk to who understands what you are going through.

In conclusion, it is important to recognize that feeling guilty or ashamed after a night of drinking is a normal and natural response. It is not a sign of a problem, but rather a sign that you are taking responsibility for your actions and are working to make positive changes in your life. If you find that these feelings are persistent and are interfering with your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a therapist or counselor. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your feelings and work with you to develop strategies for managing them in a healthy and constructive way.

thank you for sharing your struggles with me. It takes a lot of courage to admit when we're struggling with something, and I'm here to listen and offer support. It's completely understandable to feel upset or angry when someone is spreading rumors or saying negative things about you or your relationship. No one deserves to be treated with disrespect or cruelty, and it's important to stand up for yourself and your loved ones.
However, I want to encourage you to think about how you're dealing with these situations. Lashing out at the person who's causing the drama or at your boyfriend may not be the most effective way to handle the situation. It's important to find healthy ways to manage your emotions and communicate your feelings in a constructive way.
Here are a few suggestions that may help:
1. Take a step back: When you feel yourself getting upset or angry, take a deep breath and step back from the situation. Give yourself a moment to calm down before reacting.
2. Use "I" statements: When you do speak up, try using "I" statements to express your feelings. For example, "I feel upset when you say things about me. Can we find a way to resolve this?" This can help the other person understand your perspective and feel less defensive.
3. Practice empathy: Try to see things from the other person's point of view. Why do you think they might be spreading rumors or saying negative things about you? Is there something going on in their life that's causing them to act this way?
4. Communicate with your boyfriend: It's important to communicate with your partner about how their behavior is affecting you. Use "I" statements to express your feelings and work together to find a solution.
Remember, it's okay to feel upset or angry when someone is treating you with disrespect. But it's important to handle the situation in a way that doesn't hurt the people you love. With time and practice, you can learn to manage your emotions and communicate effectively in difficult situations.
Keep in mind that it's okay to ask for help along the way. Consider talking to a therapist or trusted friend or family member about your struggles. They may be able to offer additional support and guidance.
Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. Don't be afraid to stand up for yourself and your loved ones.

Response: Not liking someone is not cruel - even if it is a family member. There is nothing wrong with you for not liking your sister. Some people are fortunate to have siblings that they get along with really well, other don't. We all have different personalities and we are not going to like everyone - even if they are related. In fact, sometimes being related makes it harder because you know all of each other's flaws and imperfections. With that being said - it may be worth it to make an effort to talk about the things that get in the way of having the kind of relationship that you might ideally want with your sister. Sometimes it is hard to like someone if we have a lot of old frustration and resentment and being able to talk about it in a constructive and kind way can lead to more understanding and respect, and sometimes actually liking each other. </s>

completely understandable to feel frustrated and angry when a loved one is suffering from a degenerative illness like Alzheimer's. It can be challenging to see someone you care about change in such a profound way, and the constant requests for unrealistic or silly items can be emotionally draining.
Firstly, it's essential to recognize that your feelings are normal and valid. It's okay to feel frustrated and angry, and it's important to acknowledge these emotions rather than suppressing them. Suppressing your feelings can lead to emotional burnout and can make it more challenging to cope with the situation.
Here are some strategies that may help you cope with your feelings:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax. This can include exercise, meditation, reading, or spending time with friends and family.
2. Set boundaries: While it's important to be empathetic and understanding, it's also crucial to set boundaries and prioritize your own needs. It's okay to say no to requests that are unrealistic or that you cannot fulfill.
3. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a support group for help and guidance. Talking to others who are going through a similar experience can be incredibly helpful in providing emotional support and practical advice.
4. Focus on the positive: While it's challenging to deal with the negative aspects of Alzheimer's, try to focus on the positive aspects of your mother's personality and the memories you have shared together. This can help you maintain a positive perspective and find meaning in the situation.
5. Practice gratitude: Make a conscious effort to focus on the things you are grateful for, such as your mother's life, her memories, and the time you have shared together. Practicing gratitude can help shift your perspective and make it easier to cope with the challenges of Alzheimer's.
Remember, coping with a loved one's Alzheimer's is a challenging and emotional journey. It's essential to be patient, empathetic, and understanding, while also taking care of yourself and seeking support when needed.

Response: Sometimes repressing anger can lead to depression and block all kinds of other emotions too.  I would wonder about your experience with anger and if you've ever been discouraged from expressing anger.  I would also wonder if you feel like you have space to express yourself in your relationship or if you feel like you really aren't being heard.  It's hard to feel cared for and connected to someone else when you don't feel accepted by them. </s>

Output:
completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and concerned about your anger issues, especially when it's affecting your relationship with your partner and your children. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this struggle, and there are many resources available to help you manage your anger in a healthier way.
First of all, it's important to acknowledge that your anger is not something to be ashamed of. It's a common emotion that can arise in any situation, and it doesn't define who you are as a person. However, it's important to learn how to manage your anger in a way that doesn't negatively impact those around you.
One strategy you can try is deep breathing exercises. When you feel yourself getting angry, take a few deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm you down and give you a moment to think before reacting.
Another strategy is to identify your triggers. What are the things that make you feel angry? Is it something your partner does? Is it a particular situation? Once you identify your triggers, you can work on finding ways to avoid or cope with them.
It's also important to communicate with your partner about your anger issues. They may not realize how their behavior is affecting you, and talking about it can help them understand your perspective and find ways to support you.
Finally, consider seeking professional help. A therapist can work with you to identify the underlying causes of your anger and develop strategies for managing it in a healthier way.
Remember, managing anger is a process that takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and don't be afraid to reach out for support when you need it. With time and effort, you can learn to manage your anger in a way that benefits you and those around you.

Response: I admire your courage.If you are concerned about telling your dad regarding your gender identity, I would suggest a couple of things. There are a lot of groups or other supports for people who are working through some of the same changes that you may be going through now. I don't mean to convey that everyone thinks, feels, or acts the same by any means, but rather that it may be helpful to talk to others who have had some similar experiences.I was trying to include some links for you, but that particular button isn't functioning window. If you search for "transgender support" on Google, you'll find GLAAD and PFLAG, both of which are national organizations. This does not mean that you have to identify as "transgender," but researching that term may help you to find both national and local resources.As far as telling your dad, if that is particularly concerning for you, I suggest either talking through the details with a local therapist or considering if you have a trusted friend or family member (one who will respect your privacy with regard to who you would like to know about what you are experiencing at this time) so that you can talk with some people to have support. This may help with two things: allowing you to find some support for yourself as you work through the changes that you are going through now and also possibly talking with someone who knows your dad and may be able to talk with you regarding how or when to tell him.One thing that I tell anyone who wants to discuss something that is very important to them is to ask the person they want to talk to whether this is a good time for an important conversation. That way, you have greater chances of having the person's attention and/or not needing to end the conversation quickly. Also, please remember that you know yourself best, as each of us does. </s>
Output:
completely understandable that you may be feeling uncertain and scared about sharing this information with your dad. It's important to remember that you have the right to self-identify and express yourself in a way that feels authentic to you. It's okay to take your time and find the right moment to have this conversation with your dad, and it may be helpful to have a trusted friend or family member with you for support.
It's important to approach this conversation with empathy and respect for your dad's feelings. You might consider explaining to him that you have been doing some research and thinking about your gender identity, and that you have come to the realization that you don't feel female. Be sure to use language that feels comfortable and natural to you, and try to avoid using labels or language that may be unfamiliar or confusing to your dad.
It's also important to be prepared for the possibility that your dad may have questions or concerns, and to be patient and understanding as you work through this conversation together. Remember that this is a process of discovery and growth for both of you, and that it's okay to take things one step at a time.
If you're feeling overwhelmed or unsure of how to proceed, you may want to consider reaching out to a trusted counselor or therapist who can provide you with additional support and guidance. They can help you explore your feelings and identity, and provide you with the tools and resources you need to navigate this process with confidence and self-compassion.
Remember, you are not alone in this journey. There are many people who have gone through similar experiences, and there are also many resources available to help you along the way. Take things one step at a time, be kind to yourself, and know that you are deserving of love, respect, and understanding, no matter what your gender identity may be.

Response: Are you a teen?  This is a really hard problem for more teens (and adults) than let on.  When I was about 15, I remember asking my parent's friend, Herman, whether life gets any easier when you get older.  He said the problems are actually harder, but you gain the ability to deal with them better.  I've been an adult a long time now, and that is so true. If you need someone to talk to, consider a teacher or a school guidance counselor or someone you respect, maybe in church.  If they're good and they don't know how to help you, they may know how to get you to someone who can.  Also, the idea of not being "good enough" is a common psychological event.  In CBT it's called a "core belief," but I call it a "core lie" in my book, Living Yes, a Handbook for Being Human.  If you are serious about changing yourself, read about it  at www.LivingYes.org and pick up a copy there or on Amazon.  I hope this was helpful.  The future is filled with possibility if we don't prejudge it!  ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org) </s>
Output:
completely understandable to feel like you're not good enough at times, especially when life can be challenging and overwhelming. It's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way, and that many people struggle with similar feelings of inadequacy.
Firstly, please know that you are not alone in this feeling. Many people struggle with feelings of inadequacy, and it's okay to feel this way. It's important to remember that everyone has their own struggles and challenges, and it's okay to not be perfect.
It's great that you want to talk to your parents about how you're feeling. Sometimes, talking to someone we trust can help us feel better and gain a new perspective. However, it's important to approach the conversation in a way that feels comfortable and safe for you. You could start by expressing how you're feeling, and why. For example, you could say something like, "Hey Mom and Dad, I wanted to talk to you about something that's been on my mind lately. I've been feeling really down and like I'm not good enough, and I don't know how to deal with it. Can we talk about it?"
It's important to remember that your parents love you and want the best for you, and they may be able to offer you support and guidance. They may be able to help you identify the sources of your feelings of inadequacy and find ways to cope with them.
In addition to talking to your parents, there are other things you can do to help manage your feelings of inadequacy. Here are a few suggestions:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by doing things that make you feel good, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with friends.
2. Challenge negative thoughts: When you notice negative thoughts about yourself, try to challenge them by asking yourself if they are really true. Are there other ways to look at the situation?
3. Seek professional help: If you're feeling overwhelmed and like you can't manage your feelings of inadequacy on your own, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional support and coping strategies.
Remember, it's okay to feel like you're not good enough sometimes, and it's important to be kind to yourself as you work through these feelings. You are not alone, and there are people and resources available to help you cope.
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help with.

Response: First I am so sorry for your loss.  Most people go through the grieving process.  I would get a better understanding of what that process is.  Everyone has their own way of handling loss.  You are taking the first step in realizing that you are having a difficult time coping with it.  I would reach out to a therapist that has experience treatment patients with loss. I would also recognize that drinking and smoking are both substances that will not make depression or depressive thoughts any better. </s>
Output:
completely understandable that you are struggling to cope with the loss of your friend, and it's important to acknowledge that grief can be a complex and difficult process. However, I would like to caution you that turning to drugs and alcohol as a means of coping with grief can have serious negative consequences for your mental and emotional health, as well as your overall well-being.
Firstly, using drugs and alcohol can exacerbate feelings of depression, anxiety, and hopelessness, which can make it even harder to cope with the loss of your friend. It's important to find healthy ways to process your emotions and work through your grief, rather than turning to substances that can further complicate your mental health.
Secondly, using drugs and alcohol can also lead to physical health problems, such as liver damage, heart problems, and respiratory issues. It's important to prioritize your physical health and well-being, especially during a difficult time like this.
Instead of turning to drugs and alcohol, there are many other ways you can cope with the loss of your friend. Here are a few suggestions:
1. Allow yourself to grieve: It's important to give yourself permission to feel your emotions and to grieve the loss of your friend. This can involve taking time to reflect on your feelings, writing in a journal, or talking to a trusted friend or therapist.
2. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a support group for help and guidance. Talking to others who have experienced a similar loss can be incredibly helpful in processing your emotions and finding ways to cope.
3. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by getting enough rest, eating healthy foods, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Exercise, meditation, and yoga can also be helpful in managing stress and anxiety.
4. Find healthy ways to cope: There are many healthy ways to cope with grief, such as volunteering, creating art or music, or engaging in a hobby that you enjoy. Find activities that help you feel productive and fulfilled, and that allow you to honor the memory of your friend.
5. Seek professional help: If you are struggling to cope with your grief, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. A therapist or counselor can provide you with the tools and support you need to work through your emotions and find ways to heal.
Remember, grief is a process that takes time, patience, and support. Be kind to yourself, and don't be afraid to reach out for help when you need it.

Response: From the little bit you wrote, my guess is you haven't figured out where and how to lay down your own set of roots.Usually people who have a university level eduction are old enough to work in order to support themselves.Unless you have a medical condition which limits or prevents you from working a full-time job, would you guess that the effort and thought involved in deciding in what professional area and geographic location to look for work, would offer you a way to establish your identity?My suggestion is to pay more attention to your own likes, dislikes, and interests.   To know these areas more deeply would define the type of people with whom you identify, have a common interest and with whom you'd like to socialize.The more you realize who you are, the easier time you'll have to find like-minded others and feel securely at home with them and yourself.Again, if you have a medical disability or condition which prevents employment or easily socializing with other people, then this advice would need to be modified for your specific strengths. </s>
Output:
completely understandable to feel like you don't belong, especially when you have all the basic necessities in life. It's important to remember that belonging is not just about having material possessions, but also about feeling connected and accepted by the people around you.
It's great that you have a good education and are able to provide for yourself, but it's also important to have a sense of belonging and connection with others. It's possible that you may be feeling disconnected from others due to various reasons such as cultural or social differences, or maybe you just haven't found the right people who understand and accept you for who you are.
It's important to remember that finding belonging is a process and it may take some time and effort to find people who truly understand and accept you. Here are some things you can try:
1. Join clubs or groups that align with your interests: This could be a sports team, a book club, or a volunteer group. By joining a group of people who share your interests, you may find people who understand and accept you.
2. Attend events and gatherings: Look for events in your community that align with your interests, such as concerts, festivals, or cultural events. These events can provide opportunities to meet new people and potentially find a sense of belonging.
3. Practice self-care: Taking care of yourself and prioritizing your mental health can help you feel more connected to yourself and others. This can include activities such as meditation, exercise, or spending time in nature.
4. Seek professional help: If you're struggling to find belonging and it's impacting your daily life, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional support and guidance on how to cope with these feelings.
Remember, finding belonging is a journey and it may take some time and effort to find people who truly understand and accept you. But with persistence and patience, you can find a sense of belonging and connection with others.
In the meantime, try to focus on building self-esteem and self-worth. Practice self-compassion and remind yourself of your strengths and positive qualities. Surround yourself with people who support and accept you, even if they may not be your biological family. And don't be afraid to reach out to people who can provide you with emotional support and guidance.
You are not alone in this feeling, and there are many people who have gone through similar experiences. Remember, you are deserving of love, acceptance, and belonging, and it's okay to take your time to find it.

Response: Hi, San Diego. I'm sad that this was your first experience (in 25 years) with feeling in love. You deserve better. My understanding of today's (western?) social cultural norms is that it is somehow acceptable to abruptly stop communicating with someone you've been seeing, without explanation. I don't get it. It's rude. You're better off without this person around. There are still people who operate with respect, but this person isn't one of them.If I'm reading this right, you knew this person for a week? In my humble opinion, much heartache and many poor relationships come from attaching too soon. It takes years to get to know someone deeply. I know it's hard to keep yourself from falling in love, but you owe it to your heart to take these things more slowly, because everyone puts their best self forward at the beginning and it takes time for that to relax and for you to see who they are when times are tougher and real stuff happens.If I was your therapist, I'd be curious about how this is the first time you've fallen in love? Or is it that you were in love 25 years ago?  Was your heart broken then, or did something encourage your heart to close? What has kept you from either meeting people or letting yourself fall in love until now? Is there a danger that you will decide love isn't worth the risk? This is a crucial time for you to potentially seek professional support from a therapist in order to understand yourself and not shut down, if that's what happened before. :) </s>
Output:
completely understandable that you're feeling hurt and in pain after someone you fell in love with suddenly left without even saying goodbye. It can be incredibly difficult to process and move on from something like this, especially when it's your first time falling in love.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate your feelings. It's okay to feel hurt, angry, and confused after something like this happens. It's normal to feel like your heart is burning, and it's okay to feel like you can't take the pain.
It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone. Reach out to friends, family, or a therapist who can provide emotional support and help you process your feelings. Talking to someone who understands can help you feel less alone and more supported.
It might also be helpful to take some time for self-care. Engage in activities that make you feel good and help you relax, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time in nature. Take care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally.
Remember, it's okay to take time for yourself and to prioritize your own well-being. It's important to focus on your own healing and growth, rather than getting caught up in trying to understand or change the other person's actions.
It's also important to remember that you deserve to be treated with respect and care in a relationship. It's okay to set boundaries and prioritize your own needs and feelings. It's okay to take a step back and focus on yourself, rather than investing all of your energy into someone who doesn't seem to care about you.
Remember, you are worthy of love and respect, and you deserve to be treated with kindness and care. Take time to focus on yourself and your own healing, and don't be afraid to reach out for support when you need it.

Response: Yes, counseling can help people.How this happens is bc the counselor can guide the person or couple into deeper areas of their thoughts and emotions than the person or partners would typically avoid or not even realize they are avoiding.Also, a counseling session offers emotional safety because the therapist will intervene with thoughtful questions if someone's strong emotions overwhelm them.This is different than in everyday circumstances.  When someone feels overwhelmed by their own or someone else's feelings, there is no one who asks reflective questions.Last, people get better in therapy because often therapy is the first time the person has a chance to trust someone with their confidential information and know this information will always be protected. </s>
Output:
completely normal to have doubts and questions about the effectiveness of counseling, especially if you've never experienced it before. However, research has consistently shown that counseling can be a highly effective tool for improving mental health and well-being. Here are some reasons why:
1. A safe space to process emotions: Counseling provides a safe and confidential space for you to express your emotions and thoughts without fear of judgment. This can be incredibly helpful in processing difficult emotions and experiences.
2. Developing self-awareness: Through counseling, you can gain a deeper understanding of your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. This self-awareness can help you identify patterns and habits that may be contributing to your mental health issues, and work on making positive changes.
3. Learning coping skills: Counseling can teach you various coping skills and strategies to manage stress, anxiety, and other mental health issues. These skills can be applied in your daily life to help you navigate difficult situations more effectively.
4. Improved relationships: Counseling can help you develop healthier communication and relationship patterns, which can lead to stronger, more fulfilling relationships with friends, family, and loved ones.
5. Personal growth: Counseling can be a powerful tool for personal growth and self-improvement. Through the process of exploring your thoughts, feelings, and experiences with a trained professional, you can gain a greater understanding of yourself and develop a more positive sense of self.
6. Improved mental health: Counseling has been shown to be highly effective in improving mental health outcomes, such as reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety, improving mood, and enhancing overall well-being.

While it's normal to have doubts about counseling, it's important to remember that it's a highly effective tool for improving mental health and well-being. With the guidance of a trained professional, you can gain a deeper understanding of yourself and develop the skills and strategies needed to manage mental health issues and improve your overall quality of life.

Response: Hi there, Thank you for your openness about the challenge you are experiencing in your relationship. Sexual intimacy is an important part of many people's life, but how much importance is placed on it varies from couple to couple. The first step would be to have an open conversation with your husband. It's important you are both open about what you desire from sexual intimacy and how much intimacy each one of you wants. For example, asking your husband how often does he want to have sex/ week or /month. When having this conversation, it's important that you are both respectful and open with each other. The point of the conversation is to get to know each other and not to solve a problem, yet. There are couples who enjoy fulfilling platonic/friendship relationships with minimal or no sex because both partners are not interested in it. If you are both on the same page - lack of sex might not be a problem. If there is a difference in your sex drive and frequency of desire, I would recommend seeing a professional relationship & sex therapist as a couple to help you explore your current sexual dynamic, what's creating it, what's getting in a way of connecting sexually and to assist you and your husband in finding creative solutions. </s>
Output:
completely normal and understandable that you're feeling frustrated and concerned about the lack of intimacy in your relationship. It's important to remember that every couple is different and has their own unique rhythm and needs when it comes to sex and intimacy.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that a low sex drive or a lack of connection in the bedroom is not uncommon, and it doesn't necessarily mean that there's anything wrong with either of you. Life can get busy, and priorities can shift, which can lead to a decrease in the frequency of sex. Additionally, many factors such as stress, health issues, or simply not feeling connected can also affect libido and intimacy.
It's great that you're looking to improve your connection with your husband and work on building a stronger, more fulfilling relationship. Here are some suggestions that may help:
1. Communicate openly and honestly: It's important to talk to your husband about how you're feeling and what you need from him. Be honest and open about your desires and feelings, and listen to his perspective as well. Try to use "I" statements instead of blaming or accusing language, which can create distance and defensiveness.
2. Prioritize quality over quantity: Instead of focusing solely on the frequency of sex, consider prioritizing the quality of your connections. Take the time to connect with each other on an emotional and intellectual level, and find ways to show affection and appreciation outside of the bedroom.
3. Explore new ways of connecting: There are many ways to connect with your partner beyond sex, such as cuddling, massages, or simply spending time together doing things you both enjoy. Experiment with different activities and find what works best for you both.
4. Seek professional help: If you're struggling to connect with each other or if you're experiencing ongoing stress or tension in your relationship, consider seeking the help of a couples therapist. A therapist can provide a safe and neutral space for you both to work through any issues and improve your communication and connection.
Remember, improving your connection with your partner takes time, effort, and patience. Be kind to yourselves and each other, and keep working towards building a stronger, more fulfilling relationship.

Response:
<s> <<SYS>> Respond accordingly to the provided context. Try to give adequate counseling to the user. Show empathetic responses and naturality when answering. <</SYS>> [INST] I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
 Hello, and thank you for your question and seeking advice on this. Feelings of worthlessness is unfortunately common. In fact, most people, if not all, have felt this to some degree at some point in their life. You are not alone. Changing our feelings is like changing our thoughts - it's hard to do. Our minds are so amazing that the minute you change your thought another one can be right there to take it's place. Without your permission, another thought can just pop in there. The new thought may feel worse than the last one! My guess is that you have tried several things to improve this on your own even before reaching out on here. People often try thinking positive thoughts, debating with their thoughts, or simply telling themselves that they need to "snap out of it" - which is also a thought that carries some self-criticism. Some people try a different approach, and there are counselors out there that can help you with this. The idea is that instead of trying to change the thoughts, you change how you respond to them. You learn skills that allow you to manage difficult thoughts and feelings differently so they don't have the same impact on you that they do right now. For some people, they actually DO begin to experience less hurtful thoughts once they learn how to manage the ones they have differently. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy may be a good choice for you. There is information online and even self-help books that you can use to teach you the skills that I mentioned. Because they are skills, they require practice, but many people have found great relief and an enriched life by learning them. As for suicidal thoughts, I am very glad to read that this has not happened to you. Still, you should watch out for this because it can be a sign of a worsening depression. If you begin to think about this, it is important to reach out to a support system right away. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. The text line is #741741. I hope some other colleagues will provide you more suggestions. Be well...Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC </s>
Output:
completely normal to feel worthless at times, and it's important to remember that you are not alone in this feeling. Many people struggle with feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem, and it's okay to feel this way sometimes.
Firstly, please know that you are not worthless. You are a unique and valuable person, and you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. It's important to remember that you are more than just your thoughts and feelings – you are a complex and multi-faceted individual with your own strengths, talents, and abilities.
It's great to hear that you haven't contemplated suicide, and that you want to fix your issues. It takes a lot of courage to seek help and support, and it's important to know that there are people who care about you and want to help.
One thing that might be helpful is to talk to a mental health professional. completely understandable that you're feeling the way you do after your recent breakup. Losing someone you cared about can be incredibly difficult, and it's normal to feel a range of emotions, including sadness, anger, confusion, and fear. It's important to remember that healing takes time, and it's okay to feel vulnerable and unsure of yourself during this process.

It's okay to feel like you're not yourself or like you're not enjoying things as much as you used to. This is a normal part of the healing process.

Be kind to yourself and try not to be too hard on yourself. Remember that you're doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of.

You might also consider seeking out professional help, such as therapy or counseling, which can provide you with additional support and guidance as you navigate this difficult time.
It's also important to remember that it's okay to take things one step at a time. Healing from a breakup is not something that happens overnight, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you work through your emotions. Take things one day at a time, and try not to put too much pressure on yourself. Remember that you're doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of.

Remember that you're not alone, and that many people have gone through similar experiences. Try to be kind to yourself and focus on self-care and self-compassion.
In summary, it's okay to feel scared and unsure of yourself after a breakup. Remember to be kind to yourself and try not to be too hard on yourself as you work through this difficult time.

espond accordingly to the provided context, I understand that this can be a challenging and emotional experience for you and your family. It's important to remember that Alzheimer's disease is a degenerative condition that affects cognitive function, including memory, thinking, and decision-making. As a result, your mother may not always be able to understand or remember things the way she used to, which can be difficult for both of you.
It's completely normal to feel disappointed or frustrated when someone you love is no longer able to remember or act in the way you expect them to. However, it's important to try to separate your feelings from your mother's condition and to approach the situation with empathy and understanding.
Here are some things you can try to help manage your feelings and support your mother:

Remember, it's okay to feel upset or frustrated at times, but try not to let those feelings overwhelm you. By staying calm, patient, and empathetic, you can help your mother feel more comfortable and secure in her own skin.
I hope these suggestions are helpful. Remember that you're not alone in this journey, and there are many resources available to support you and your family.

Response: In dealing with an eating disorder you are far from alone.  It is more common than you might think and tied to so many variables that it is easy for an individual to become overwhelmed in trying to navigate the influences of such variables.  I have been working with individuals dealing with such challenges since 1998 and have found over the years that behavioral analysis is highly effective in helping you begin to isolate, understand and then be able to address many of these variable impacting your behavioral and cognitive choices.  Consider finding someone trained in Dialectic Behavior Therapy (DBT).  There is a large body of evidence supporting the use of this approach to alleviating many of the aspects you identified in your post as well of a wide variety of tools that you can choose from and utilize that are able to practiced and assimilated into your daily tool box of coping mechanisms that end up becoming new behaviors and ways of thinking about issues that become automatic, the best possible outcome you can hope for if you want the solution to be sustainable. </s>
Output:
completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and frustrated with binge eating, especially during times of stress. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this struggle, and there are many coping mechanisms that can help you break this cycle. Here are some suggestions that may be helpful:
1. Practice mindful eating: When you feel the urge to binge eat, try to slow down and be more mindful of your eating habits. Pay attention to your hunger and fullness cues, and try to eat more slowly and savor your food. This can help you better recognize when you're feeling hungry or full, and can reduce the likelihood of binge eating.
2. Identify and manage triggers: Take some time to reflect on when and why you tend to binge eat. Is it when you're feeling stressed or anxious? Is it after a certain time of day? Once you identify your triggers, you can start working on ways to manage them. For example, if you tend to binge eat after work, try to find a different way to relax, like taking a walk or practicing deep breathing exercises.
3. Seek support: Talk to a trusted friend or family member about your struggles with binge eating. They may be able to offer emotional support and help you stay accountable. You could also consider joining a support group for people with eating disorders, where you can connect with others who are going through similar experiences.
4. Practice self-compassion: It's important to be kind and compassionate towards yourself when you do binge eat. Instead of beating yourself up over it, try to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that it's okay to make mistakes. Remember that recovering from an eating disorder is a process, and it's okay to take things one step at a time.
5. Consider therapy: Working with a therapist can be incredibly helpful in addressing the underlying issues that contribute to binge eating. A therapist can help you identify patterns and triggers, and work with you to develop coping mechanisms and strategies for managing stress and emotions in a healthier way.
Remember, breaking the cycle of binge eating takes time and patience, but it is possible. Don't be too hard on yourself, and try to focus on making progress rather than perfection. You got this!

Response: You're right that long-distance relationships can be complicated. If he loves you and you love him, that's a great start. I wonder if you would be able or willing to have a discussion about what you love about each other and what makes each of you feel loved, valued, special, and appreciated.When having important discussions, consider the following:Make sure it is a good time to have a discussion (and if you're doing it in writing because of the distance, you could type something in the top of the message about not reading any further if the person who is reading doesn't have 10 minutes or something like that)Try to listen as though you are an investigative reporter trying to find out information about each other. Asking more questions in this manner can be a helpful way to be less defensive during difficult or emotional conversations.When having discussions face-to-face, I often recommend using timeout when things become very emotional and saying that you agree to go back to the conversation in 15 minutes or one hour or some short duration of time that allows for some of the immediate emotions to dissipate so it is easier to also talk about them. As for how that translates to distance, maybe each of you would say that you are working on figuring out how best to explain it and will answer the next time you have access to the Internet (or, if possible, use some kind of timeframe).Consider what questions you would like answers to. For example, are you wondering:What should I do if I miss you or want to talk to you more? I don't want to make you feel guilty, but I also don't want to hide my feelings. Can I share them with you?If you have days or weeks when we cannot be in contact directly, can I keep sending you messages or is that overwhelming?How will you ask for support from me?Some couples really want to protect each other. In doing so, instead of hiding our emotions, can we share them and work through them together?Whatever else comes to mind.Gary Chapman is famous for his books about the 5 Love Languages. He has one specifically for military families: The 5 Love Languages Military Edition: The Secret to Love That Lasts.Here's a list of books related to loving from a distance: http://www.longdistancerelationships.net/bookstor.htmI have not read these books myself, but I have read other works by a lot of the authors.One final tip: Consider making a list of times when you work together and both feeling calm, safe, and comfortable. These memories could be helpful to you during difficult moments.Best wishes to you. Remember that you could each see therapists in your respective locations if that would be helpful to you. </s>

Communication opens up what is called "cognitive space" for your partner, and allows them to do the same for you. The more you know about each other, especially your everyday lives, creates a bond between the two of you. Much like the saying goes in the military, the same is true for a couple; "Complacency Kills". It is important for both of you to invest in each other on a regular basis. I regularly recommend that both of you take the 5 Love Languages Assessment and start using each other's top love languages to help show each other the positive affection that you feel (or at least want to feel) for one another. Start asking about your husband's day, trying to learn about all the interactions that he has at work, and feel free to ask questions so that he knows you really want to know about him, and know him intimately again. </s>

completely normal to feel disconnected from your partner after many years of marriage. It's common for people to grow apart, especially as they go through different stages of life. However, it's important to remember that communication and effort can help you reconnect and strengthen your relationship. Here are some things you can try:
1. Have an open and honest conversation: Sit down with your husband and have a calm, respectful conversation about how you're feeling. Be specific about the things that are making you feel disconnected and uncared for. Try to use "I" statements instead of "you" statements, which can come across as accusatory. For example, you could say, "I feel like we've grown apart in the past few years, and I'm feeling really lonely and unsupported. I want us to work on reconnecting and feeling closer again."
2. Identify common interests: Take some time to think about what you and your husband used to enjoy doing together, and see if there are any activities you can do together again. This can help you reconnect and create new memories together. You could try taking a class, going on a weekend trip, or simply spending time together doing something you both enjoy.
3. Make time for each other: With busy schedules, it can be easy to let quality time with your partner fall by the wayside. Make a conscious effort to set aside time each week to spend together, whether it's a date night or just a quiet evening at home. This can help you feel more connected and strengthen your relationship.
4. Practice empathy and active listening: Sometimes, when we feel disconnected from our partner, it's because we're not really listening to each other or understanding each other's perspectives. Practice active listening and empathy by really paying attention to what your husband is saying, and trying to see things from his point of view. This can help you feel more connected and understanding of each other.
5. Seek outside help: If you've tried these things and still feel disconnected from your husband, it may be helpful to seek outside help. Consider couples therapy, which can provide a safe and supportive environment to work through your issues and improve your communication and connection.

Remember, reconnecting with your partner takes time, effort, and patience. It's important to be kind to each other and to work together to build a stronger, more connected relationship.

completely understandable to be concerned about your daughter's well-being, especially if she's experiencing excessive stress and emotional distress. Response: Counselling offers a number of ways to help one to improve their situation.  For some, this process can take a very long, winding path of self-discovery, while, for others, they are seeking a purposeful, solution-based way to approach and manage a specific problem. It's important to remember that there are different styles of therapy, some of which will work great with some, but poorly with others, specifically to help those to decide how they wish to move forward. I often recommend speaking with a number of therapists before beginning treatment to find out more about how they practice, in order to make sure their style aligns with your goals. On a more specific note, there is myriad research out in the world that indicates both counselling and medication can have an affect on changing our moods and behaviours.  However, medication is not an effective way of treating the problem, as it treats the symptoms of that problem (increased anxiety, lowered mood, etc.) and research has shown that the most effective route for better mental health care comes from a combination of counselling and medication. </s>
Output:
completely normal to have doubts and questions about the effectiveness of counseling, especially if you've never experienced it before. However, research has consistently shown that counseling can be a highly effective form of therapy for a wide range of mental health issues. Here are some reasons why:
1. A safe space to process emotions: Counseling provides a confidential and non-judgmental space for you to express your feelings and emotions. This can be incredibly helpful in allowing you to process and work through difficult emotions and experiences.
2. Developing self-awareness: Through counseling, you can gain a deeper understanding of your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. This increased self-awareness can help you identify patterns and habits that may be contributing to your mental health issues, and work on making positive changes.
3. Learning coping skills: Counseling can teach you various coping skills and strategies to help you manage stress, anxiety, and other mental health issues. These skills can be applied in your daily life to help you feel more in control and resilient.
4. Improved relationships: Counseling can help you develop healthier communication and relationship skills, which can lead to improved interactions with family, friends, and colleagues.
5. Personal growth: Counseling can be a powerful tool for personal growth and development. Through therapy, you can learn to identify and challenge limiting beliefs and behaviors, and work towards becoming the best version of yourself.
6. Improved mental health: Counseling can help you manage symptoms of mental health conditions such as depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Research has shown that counseling can lead to significant improvements in mental health and well-being.
7. Reduced stigma: Counseling can help reduce the stigma associated with mental health issues, as it promotes a more open and accepting attitude towards mental health.
8. Improved physical health: Studies have shown that counseling can have a positive impact on physical health, including lower blood pressure, improved sleep quality, and reduced chronic pain.
9. Accessibility: Counseling is widely available and accessible, with many therapists offering online or telephone sessions for those who may have difficulty accessing in-person therapy.
10. Cost-effective: Counseling is often covered by insurance, making it a cost-effective option for mental health support.

In conclusion, counseling can be a highly effective form of therapy for a wide range of mental health issues. By providing a safe space to process emotions, developing self-awareness, learning coping skills, improving relationships, and promoting personal growth, counseling can lead to significant improvements in mental health and well-being. While it's normal to have doubts and questions about the effectiveness of counseling, the evidence suggests that it can be a powerful tool for mental health support.

For example, you could say something like, "Hey, I've noticed that you've been calling me names lately, and it's really hurtful. Can we find a way to communicate that doesn't involve name-calling?" 💬
If the behavior continues after you've talked to them, it might be best to distance yourself from the person or situation. You deserve to be treated with respect and kindness, and it's okay to prioritize your own emotional well-being. 🌟
Remember, you don't have to deal with this kind of behavior alone. If you're feeling overwhelmed or unsure of how to handle the situation, consider talking to a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional for support. 🤝
💕 Take care of yourself and remember that you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect! 💕

 Since you're aware of your sensitivity to being among large groups of people, then continue to satisfy this and stay away from crowds as much as reasonably possible.It is also fine to prefer the companionship of animals, as long as it is not to the exclusion of relationships with people.Recognizing this feature about yourself is another example of self-understanding.The only point to consider is the reason you avoid talking with other people.If its because of bad or stressful encounters, betrayals or some type of violation, then having this relationship pattern remain in your mind, may introduce new problems such as loneliness from lack of close friends.What you should do is honestly understand whether you avoid people from fear of being hurt or exploited in some way or because you genuinely prefer solitude.If you have the right combination of people/solitude/animals, then great!If not, then consider the confidential office of a therapist for new understanding of yourself and your social interests. </s>
Output:
*listens attentively* Wow, it sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and anxious in large crowds, and it's okay to prefer the company of animals sometimes. It's important to remember that you don't have to face this feeling alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help.
First of all, it might be helpful to try and identify the source of your anxiety in crowds. Is it specific situations or events that trigger your feelings of anxiety? Are there any particular sensory stimuli that make you feel uncomfortable? Once you can identify the root cause of your anxiety, you might be able to develop strategies to manage it.
In the meantime, there are a few things you can try to help manage your anxiety in crowds:
* Practice deep breathing exercises: When you start to feel anxious in a crowd, try taking a few deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your body and mind.
* Find a safe space: If you're in a crowd and feeling overwhelmed, try to find a quiet spot where you can take a break and recharge. This could be a corner of a room, a separate room, or even just a few steps away from the main crowd.
* Use positive self-talk: When you're feeling anxious, it can be easy to get caught up in negative thoughts. Try to counteract this by using positive self-talk. Instead of focusing on your anxiety, try to focus on things that make you feel good, like your accomplishments or your loved ones.
* Seek support: It can be really helpful to talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling. This could be a friend, family member, or mental health professional. Talking through your feelings can help you process them and feel more supported.
Remember, it's okay to feel overwhelmed and anxious sometimes. It's important to take care of yourself and seek support when you need it. You don't have to face this feeling alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help. *smiles*
How are you doing? Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any questions you have?

Response: Hello, and thank you for your question. First, I want to tell you how sorry I am for the experience you had with your parents. That is a grief and trauma that is certainly hard to imagine. Trauma and grief can affect us in many ways, and certainly deeply personal things like our sex lives. It may be difficult for others to make the connection, but it is there. So, for example, if stress and trauma make you feel like you are not interested in sex, a partner may take it as a personal rejection rather than response to stress, trauma or grief. If your husband will agree to it, couple's counseling may be your best bet. A counselor can help you with your communication and may be able to provide some education to your husband about trauma and how it can have an impact on intimacy. If he doesn't agree to go, it may be worth it to go on your own. You still have a lot you are dealing with yourself. And sometimes our personally therapy can influence others, so it may be a good idea. It is important to remember that even though you are married you have the right to make decisions about your body, and that includes when you want to have sex with it. I hope this is helpful, and some of my colleagues may have ideas, also. Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC </s>
