Response: It can be really tough to tell someone - anyone - that you're feeling depressed. But finding that supportive person that you can share with is a big part of the battle with depression. Depression thrives on being secret, it seems to grow the more we isolate ourselves and hide it away so I'm with Laura Cassidy, when she suggests finding that professional support person so you can start fighting back against your depression. If that feels like too big a step right now, maybe check out a book or two... I'm a big fan of a book called 'Feeling Good' by Dr. David Burns if you want some practical thoughts on tackling depression and on 'Radical Acceptance' by Tara Brach if you prefer something a little more spiritual. </s>

completely understandable to feel hesitant or scared about sharing your struggles with depression with others. Response: I couldn't help but notice that you did not specify your age, so I am unable to set the total chronological order and length that you have suffered in this way, but I want to start by commending you on seeking out additional coping techniques on your own.  Unfortunately, it sounds like you were offered some that were more dangerous than helpful, but be proud that you were able to curb those before they caused too much harm. From what you have written, stress has always been a difficult thing for you to manage.  Often, when I am working with those who offer the same concern, there is a degree of people pleasing that comes with that stress.  When we are trying to make others happy, especially when we are unable to distinguish the proper "rules for success", it can make even the simplest of tasks overwhelming. Stress management is just that, management; of our own anxieties about the needs of others, about our skills and the ability to complete a task and having multiple requests at any given time. Each of these aspects requires a separate sets of "tools" to manage them accordingly. For example, assertiveness communication training could aid in communicating with your colleagues to manage their expectations of your deadlines and abilities, but it will not assist you with managing your own anxieties. Try to separate the different areas of the problem, in order to help yourself to find a solution and work on them in their own time. Perhaps keeping a journal will help you to better understand why you are so easily overwhelmed by stress and help you track some of your less-helpful responses to stress. For example, does a certain person's style of communication always make you feel undervalued and therefore push you to finish their requests first? Is there a certain time of the day where you start to fall off in productivity?  Is that the time fo the day where you also tend to pile up your requirements?Try to ask yourself some of these harder questions and see where they lead you. </s>

Response: Everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect. Having said that, everyone gets upset once in awhile and may yell or scream, which can be disrespectful. You said "always, and I mean always" and that is troubling. If your dad curses and screams at you on a regular and consistent basis, it can (as you stated) impact the way you feel about yourself. While the definitions of child abuse differ from state to state, talking to someone can help. Perhaps there is a counselor at school, or another trustworthy person you could confide in to help you understand how this situation is impacting you? Counseling is a good option. There is also help available through the national hotline at 1-800-422-4453, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. You can call (press 1) and talk to a counselor while being anonymous. You can also check out this website: https://www.childhelp.org/hotline/resources-kids/I am sorry that you are going though this situation. There is help available. You do not have to go through this situation alone. </s>

completely understandable that you feel upset and hurt by your father's behavior towards you. It's important to recognize that his actions are not acceptable and can have a significant impact on your well-being.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your father's behavior is not okay. It's not acceptable for someone to constantly criticize, belittle, or compare you unfavorably to others in a negative way. This kind of behavior can be emotionally abusive and can make you feel worthless, anxious, or depressed.
It's important to remember that you are not alone in this situation. Many people have to deal with similar situations, and there are resources available to help you cope with it. Response: Your instinct to help your daughter, is natural.How you proceed depends a lot on whether she recognizes she has a psychological and emotional problem, or if only you see this from observing her.Also, her age matters a lot in what way would be most likely to succeed in addressing the problems you describe.If you and your daughter have different opinions as to whether or not she has problems, and she is above the legal age of when you have authority over her life, then you can only suggest to her that therapy may benefit her.If your daughter is in your legal control, then you can locate a counselor nearby, discuss your situation with that person, and depending on the outcome, you'd be within your parenting right to take your daughter to a counselor.Starting therapy without willingness to do so, is risky.  The person may feel resentful enough to not participate.   And, sometimes the counselor is skillful enough to find a path to your daughter, or any patient's self-interest and engage them in therapy.Family counseling, regardless of your daughter's age, is another way to bring your concerns to your daughter's attention, in a therapy environment in which a counselor would be able to help distinguish the seriousness of your daughter's psychological problem, from simply a difference in viewpoints between you and your daughter, in how to handle certain situations.Also, if you believe your daughter is a threat to herself, then instead of this slower route, get in touch with the emergency psychological assessment service in your town, for a more immediate response. </s>

Response: I am sorry to hear that you are going through such a tough time. It sounds to me like you are suffering from depression to some degree. Have you seen a therapist or talked to anyone about your problems? If not, I would advise that you do so sooner than later so that you can learn what is causing you to be unmotivated and causing difficulty with breaking the cycle that you are in. It is also a good idea to get a medical evaluation from your doctor to rule out any medical causes for your current condition. Most often, difficult situations that life throws at us, along with an inability to think positively, and break bad habits are what cause depression. Some things you can do immediately are seek help from a professional, schedule in time every day to engage in pleasurable (or once pleasurable) activities, exercise daily, and practice thinking more positively. Set a few daily goals for yourself and write them down each morning or the night before. Achieving your goals every day will give you a sense of accomplishment and can lead to feeling more optimistic and capable. Additionally, keep a journal to write down how you are feeling and what ideas you have to help feel better. Sometimes having these ideas written down make it more real and tangible. Know that depression is most often curable but takes work and a desire to change (which you clearly have). Once you start feeling better about yourself and your life, your grades should naturally begin to improve, as you will have more motivation and energy to focus on that particular area. Best of luck to you! </s>
Output:
*empathetic voice* Oh no, it sounds like you're really struggling with procrastination and it's impacting your academic performance. It's completely understandable to feel frustrated and disappointed in yourself when you know you're capable of better. Procrastination can be a tough habit to break, but it's important to remember that you're not alone and there are ways to overcome it.
Firstly, let's acknowledge that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and stuck. It's normal to feel this way, especially when you're facing a challenge that seems insurmountable. It's important to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that you're doing the best you can.
Now, let's talk about some strategies that might help you break the cycle of procrastination. One thing that can be helpful is to identify the reasons behind your procrastination. Are you feeling overwhelmed by the task? Are you lacking motivation? Once you understand the reasons, you can start working on ways to address them. For example, if you're feeling overwhelmed, you could break the task down into smaller, more manageable chunks. Or, if you're lacking motivation, you could find ways to make the task more interesting or rewarding.
Another strategy is to use the Pomodoro technique. This involves working in focused, 25-minute increments, followed by a five-minute break. This can help you stay focused and avoid distractions.
It's also important to create a conducive study environment. This could mean finding a quiet, comfortable space to study, or using noise-cancelling headphones to block out distractions.
Lastly, remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Whether it's a friend, family member, or academic advisor, don't be afraid to reach out for support.
Remember, breaking the cycle of procrastination takes time and effort, but it's worth it. You can do it, and you deserve to achieve your academic goals. *smiling empathetically* How do you feel now?

Response: That you are questioning if you should end your relationship with your boyfriend tells me that you are unhappy with him. Spend sometime by yourself exploring the reasons for that unhappiness. Are these things likely to change or not? </s>

First of all, my heart goes out to you. Infidelity is an extremely challenging obstacle to overcome. There are some things that you should consider. First of all, did he seem truly remorseful? If you felt in his heart that he was truly sorry for what he had done, it will give you a piece of mind that it was a  mistake. Secondly, was he forthcoming with this information? How about with answering your questions after the truth was uncovered? If you found that he was still lying or not forthcoming, the sting is even more painful. He should be able to answer any question you have honestly and without hesitation.Thirdly, has he shown a positive difference after this experience? At this time, he should still be proving his faithfulness to the marriage, you and the children.Keep in mind that experiencing infidelity is a form of grief. It is not a quick process that can easily be overcome. What you are experiencing is 100% normal. My best suggestion would be to see a marriage therapist. Find out what drove your husband to cheat in the first place and decide if this aspect in his life has been resolved. I know its important for you to keep your family together but children can sense anger and frustration, this is not a healthy environment either. If you decide that you can no longer remain in the relationship, a therapist will also be able to help you cope with the separation along with addressing your children's needs.Please know that you are not alone and that unfortunately, many relationships have endured this very thing. It may also be helpful to reach out to people who have experienced similar obstacles. The web is a great resource to find groups whether online or in person to use as a support or sounding board.Best of luck to you and your family! </s>

completely understandable that you're struggling to move on from this person you fell in love with, especially when the feelings he showed you are so rare and special. It's important to recognize that it's okay to feel this way and that it's normal to feel conflicted when it comes to love.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate your feelings. It's okay to feel a deep connection with someone, even if it's considered "wrong" by society. It's important to remember that love knows no boundaries, and it's okay to feel this way, even if it's not the socially accepted norm.
It's understandable that you don't want to be without the genuine love you feel for this person, but it's important to consider the bigger picture. It's important to think about your own well-being and happiness, and to consider whether staying in this situation is truly the best for you. It's okay to take time to process your feelings and to think about what you want for yourself.
One way to start moving on is to focus on self-care and self-compassion. Take time for yourself, engage in activities that make you happy, and practice self-love. It's important to remember that you deserve to be happy and to find love that is healthy and fulfilling.
Another way to move on is to find ways to honor and respect the feelings you have for this person. You don't have to cut them out of your life completely, but you can find ways to acknowledge and appreciate the connection you have without getting caught up in the same patterns of thinking and feeling.
Remember, moving on from someone you love is never easy, but it's possible. Take your time, be kind to yourself, and focus on your own well-being. With time and support, you can find a way to move forward in a way that feels true to you.
It's important to remember that you don't have to do this alone. Consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who can provide you with additional support and guidance as you navigate this difficult time. They can help you process your feelings and find ways to move on in a healthy and fulfilling way.
Remember, you deserve to be happy and to find love that is healthy and fulfilling. Take your time, be kind to yourself, and know that you will get through this.

   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
 If everyone thinks you're worthless, then maybe you need to find new people to hang out with.Seriously, the social context in which a person lives is a big influence in self-esteem.Otherwise, you can go round and round trying to understand why you're not worthless, then go back to the same crowd and be knocked down again.There are many inspirational messages you can find in social media.  Maybe read some of the ones which state that no person is worthless, and that everyone has a good purpose to their life.Also, since our culture is so saturated with the belief that if someone doesn't feel good about themselves that this is somehow terrible.Bad feelings are part of living.  They are the motivation to remove ourselves from situations and relationships which do us more harm than good.Bad feelings do feel terrible.   Your feeling of worthlessness may be good in the sense of motivating you to find out that you are much better than your feelings today. </s>
Output:
completely understandable to feel worthless and struggle with negative thoughts at times. It's important to remember that these feelings are not a reflection of your true worth as a person. You are deserving of love, care, and respect, regardless of any challenges you may be facing.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate your feelings. It's okay to feel worthless at times, and it's important to give yourself permission to feel this way. It's okay to not be okay, and it's important to be kind to yourself as you work through these feelings.
Next, it may be helpful to try to identify the sources of these feelings. Are there specific events or experiences that are contributing to these feelings? Are there any negative self-talk patterns or beliefs that are perpetuating these feelings? Once you can identify the sources of these feelings, you can start to work on addressing them.
One way to address these feelings is through cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of therapy that can help you identify and challenge negative thought patterns and behaviors, and replace them with more positive and constructive ones. A therapist can work with you to identify the distorted or unhelpful thinking patterns that are contributing to your feelings of worthlessness, and teach you new ways of thinking and behaving that can help you feel more positive and confident.
Another way to address these feelings is through self-care and self-compassion. It's important to take care of yourself, both physically and emotionally, when you're feeling worthless. This can involve engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, reading, or spending time with loved ones. It's also important to be kind and compassionate to yourself, and to practice self-compassion when you're feeling down.
Finally, it may be helpful to reach out for support from friends, family, or a mental health professional. Talking through your feelings with someone who cares about you can be a powerful way to gain perspective and feel less alone. You can also seek out support groups or online forums where you can connect with others who are going through similar experiences.
Remember, it's okay to feel worthless at times, and it's important to be kind and compassionate to yourself as you work through these feelings. With time, support, and self-care, you can start to feel more positive and confident, and work towards a more fulfilling life.

Response: One way to concentrate is that if your mind starts to wonder then remind yourself to bring your attention back.Start with short time spans of expecting yourself to concentrate.  You'll more likely succeed with concentrating with small time spans than longer ones.Once you start seeing your success, this will motivate you to try increasing the length to expect yourself to concentrate.The task of self-reminding is the same, whether for long or short time periods.Also, before starting this exercise ask your medical doctor if the problem can be related to a physical health problem.If there is, then have the possibility ruled out that your difficulty concentrating comes from the mental ability to concentrate, and not some medical reason preventing this.Before someone can engage their psychological will there must be a clean medical body and mind with which to work. </s>

Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.
 I'm alway wary of assigning a term to a feeling, as often that term becomes more important than the feeling itself. From the very little that you have written, it is clear that you are going through something that has made you extremely low, affected your self-esteem and motivation, limits your enjoyment of formerly pleasurable activities and affects your feelings of self-worth. All of these are aspects of being depressed, though you can be depressed and still not have "depression". Counseling is definitely a place where you can go and sort out why you have had such a sudden a drastic change to your mood. Sometimes our mood can be effected by changes in our routine, losses or significant disappointments. Talking with someone will not only help you to better understand why you are feeling this way, but they will also help you to ground yourself and learn strategies and tools to help you to manage your mood and strategize for the future. I do hope that you will reach out. Feeling alone can be harmful over long periods of time, as it can stop us from seeking out the support we need. </s>
Output:
unds like you're going through a tough time right now. It's completely normal to feel this way, especially during the teenage years. It can be challenging to navigate the ups and downs of life, especially when it feels like everything is changing so quickly.
Firstly, it's important to know that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people, including myself, have gone through similar experiences. It's okay to feel lost, unsure of yourself, and struggling to connect with others. It's important to remember that these feelings are temporary, and they will pass with time and support.
It's possible that you might be experiencing some symptoms of depression. Depression is a common mental health condition that can cause feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and disconnection from others. If you're feeling these feelings consistently and they're interfering with your daily life, it might be worth speaking with a mental health professional. They can help you develop coping strategies and provide support during this challenging time.
However, it's also possible that you're just going through a normal phase of adolescence. Teenagers often experience mood swings and can feel disconnected from their friends and family. This can be especially true during times of change, like the transition to college. It's important to remember that these feelings are normal and will pass with time.
In the meantime, there are some things you can try to help manage your feelings:
1. Practice self-care: Make sure you're taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and spiritually. This can include things like getting enough sleep, eating healthy foods, exercising regularly, and doing activities that bring you joy.
2. Reach out to friends and family: It can be helpful to talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling. This can help you feel less alone and provide emotional support.
3. Try journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can help you process and understand them better. It can also be a helpful way to express yourself when you don't feel like talking to anyone else.
4. Take breaks from social media: Social media can be a source of stress and comparison for many people. Try taking a break from social media for a few days or a week to see how you feel.

Remember, you're not alone in this. Many people have gone through similar experiences, and there are resources available to help you. Don't be afraid to reach out for support when you need it. Take care of yourself, and know that things will get better with time.

Response: This is so very common in this crazy looks-obsessed world! I meet so many beautiful people who can't see their beauty. Is there something getting in the way for you? Was there a time in your life when people teased you or told you something hurtful, or did something to you that made you feel ugly? If so, this can be addressed first. Sometimes stories are told about us when we're young and the best thing we can do is see the author's evil or careless intent and not take that on. A therapist can help you with this part.Once you've addressed any past barriers to feeling confident, you can focus on a few simple things. First, your thoughts. If you keep telling yourself that you don't like what you see, then you will never feel okay about your looks. Experiment with telling yourself something different. Look in the mirror and I dare you to find something that's lovely about your face. Focus on that. Describe what you see? If you were your own best friend, what would you say about your face? Eliminating those negative scripts and building new positive ones will help you feel more accepting of how you look. You can't change your face, but you can change your attitude towards your face. Confidence is the things that will make you beautiful!Accepting how you look is important. Without going to plastic surgery (the popularity of which is a testimony to how nuts this whole thing has become), you were born with that nose, those eyes, those lips. Accepting yourself and knowing it won't change is a good idea, because wishing it were different won't make it so!Looking good is also about minimizing flaws and building on your assets. Are you in a rut about hairstyle or makeup? Ask a good friend to give you a make-over. Play with your features and wardrobe. There are plenty of average looking people who know how to make themselves shine because they are creative! </s>
Output:
completely normal to have feelings of insecurity or dissatisfaction with one's appearance from time to time. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this feeling, and that many people struggle with body image issues.
Firstly, it's important to recognize that these feelings are not a reflection of your worth as a person. You are more than just your physical appearance, and you have so much to offer the world. It's okay to have flaws and imperfections – everyone does!
It sounds like you might be struggling with the idea of talking to your parents about how you're feeling. It can be difficult to open up to someone we love and trust about our insecurities, but it's important to remember that they want the best for you and are there to support you. Consider talking to a trusted friend, teacher, or counselor instead – they can offer you a safe and non-judgmental space to talk about your feelings.
In the meantime, here are a few things you can try to help manage your feelings:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by doing things that make you feel good, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with friends who make you feel happy and supported.
2. Challenge negative self-talk: When you catch yourself thinking negative thoughts about your appearance, try to reframe them in a more positive light. For example, instead of thinking "I hate my face," try thinking "I have a unique and beautiful face that makes me who I am."
3. Focus on your strengths: Rather than focusing on your perceived flaws, try to focus on your strengths and the things you like about yourself.
4. Seek out positive role models: Surround yourself with people who are confident and comfortable in their own skin – they can be a great source of inspiration and support.
Remember, it's okay to have feelings of insecurity from time to time, and it's important to be kind to yourself as you work through them. You are not alone, and there are people and resources available to help you feel more confident and comfortable in your own skin.

 Relationships at any amount of distance can be so hard! It makes sense that you are encountering more anxiety than usual given that major change in your relationship. Output:
completely understandable to feel lost, sad, and unwanted when your partner is away a lot due to their new job. It can be challenging to adjust to this new dynamic in your relationship, especially if you are not used to it. It's important to remember that it's normal for relationships to go through ups and downs, and this is just one of those times.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge your feelings and give yourself time to process them. It's okay to feel upset or lonely when your partner is away, and it's important to allow yourself to feel these emotions rather than trying to suppress them.
One thing you can do to cope with this challenge is to communicate openly and honestly with your partner. Let them know how you are feeling and why. Be specific about how their absence is affecting you and ask them if there is anything they can do to help you feel more connected and supported.
It may also be helpful to find ways to stay connected with your partner while they are away. This could be as simple as scheduling regular phone or video calls, or finding activities that you can do together remotely, such as playing online games or watching movies together.
Additionally, consider reaching out to friends, family, or a therapist for support. Talking to someone who understands can be incredibly helpful in processing your emotions and finding ways to cope with this challenge.
Remember, it's okay to feel overwhelmed and it's important to be kind to yourself as you navigate this challenge. With time and effort, you can find ways to cope and stay connected with your partner even when they are away.
Lastly, it may be helpful to reflect on why you think your partner is acting this way. Is there something going on in their life that you are not aware of? Are there any underlying issues that could be contributing to their absence? Try to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, and see if there is anything you can do to help them feel more connected and supported as well.

Response: This can be really anxiety-producing when you have not felt it before. It may be helpful to work through some of this with a local therapist so you can get more specific ideas.Some other things that come to my mind are maybe talking about spending about 10 minutes or so discussing how you are feeling and seeing if your partner is willing to listen. Then you could ask questions about how she would react if you were doing something she did not like. This allows you to react to information she is actually giving you rather than your perceptions that sound like they are different than what she is trying to tell you. This gives you the power to receive the messages that she is sending to you.I would also wonder where you have learned that there wasn't much good out there for you and how you can stay present in the moment when you are with your girlfriend and see that she wants to be there with you. Perhaps you could look at what makes you feel emotionally safe and trusting with her and focus on that. You could even remind yourself "okay, I'm here with [name of girlfriend] and this is okay when I'm with her."We all have different levels of defenses in situations in which different people. It's common for people to see these things as black and white (either totally open or very self-protective. In reality, it's much more like a rainbow and the different shades of color that are available in the rainbow spectrum of white light (it's not really Just red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet that we all know, but an infinite spectrum of shades of colors that fade from one into the next). You can change your level of defensiveness with your girlfriend depending upon the location you are in, the mood you are both in, the subject, etc. There are infinite numbers of choices and you can experiment.Another thing that could help is to communicate about communication. If one of you uses a phrase that triggers something from earlier in your life or is really uncomfortable, you could discuss that. If she says certain things that make you feel really comfortable, you could discuss that as well.Hopefully you can learn more about yourselves and each other at the same time. </s>

Response: Great question. The decision to pursue therapy can be a very difficult one and the fact that there seem to be so many profiles that you have to wade through can be particularly daunting. Here's what I suggest to make the process a bit easier: 1) Narrow down your preferred geographical area. Are you in a rural, suburban, or urban environment? If it's either of the latter two, you'll probably have a mental health professional close by. Decide now if it's important to you that their office be within walking or short driving distance. 2) Decide if you need it to be covered by your insurance. You'll have more options if you're willing to pay out of pocket and get reimbursed by your insurance, but more and more people are accepting insurance these days. 3) Find someone whose profile has the key words that you're looking for. If you're struggling with traumatic flashbacks, make sure they have "trauma" or something along those lines in their profile.4) Make sure they have a friendly and professional picture. This is small, but this detail shows that they really care about how they present to the world. 5) Come up with a list of about 3 people and rank them from most appealing to least. Set up an appointment with the person who seems like the best fit and give it a try for the first session. You'll know by the end of it if it's a good fit.It can be scary, but finding the perfect fit makes it so worth it. Good luck! </s>
Output:
great that you're considering seeking professional counseling! Starting the counseling process can seem daunting, but it's actually quite straightforward. Here are some steps you can take to get started:
1. Identify your goals: What do you want to achieve through counseling? Are you feeling overwhelmed or stressed? Do you want to work through a specific issue or problem? Being clear about your goals will help you find a counselor who is a good fit for you.
2. Find a counselor: You can find a counselor through your insurance provider, online directories, or by asking for referrals from friends, family, or healthcare professionals. Make sure to check the counselor's credentials, experience, and availability before scheduling an appointment.
3. Schedule an appointment: Once you've found a counselor, schedule an appointment. Some counselors offer online or telephone sessions, while others may only see clients in-person. Choose the format that works best for you and your counselor.
4. Be honest and open: When you first meet with your counselor, be honest and open about your reasons for seeking counseling. Don't be afraid to share your thoughts, feelings, and experiences. Your counselor is there to listen and help you work through your challenges.
5. Be consistent: Counseling is a process that requires commitment and consistency. Make sure to attend your scheduled sessions and be open to the counseling process. Consistency is key to making progress and achieving your goals.
Remember, starting the counseling process takes courage and vulnerability. Be kind to yourself and recognize that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Good luck!

Response: Hi Texas, Thanks for your honesty; it helps me know where to go in answering you. What strikes me in your question is that you describe several ways in which your husband is hurtful/abusive/controlling with you, and then you ask "Should we call it quits?". We? I wonder if maybe the first step is for you to start seeing this decision as yours, rather than yours together. The way your husband treats you is not your fault, Texas. Your lies are a natural and normal way of you avoiding situations and encounters that feel unsafe for you. The problem is not your lying. The problem is that you don't feel safe enough to be honest with a person you're supposed to be able to trust.There's an analogy that I sometimes use; I don't know if this is scientifically true or simply a useful story, but it's powerful either way, so I will tell it to you.If you take a frog and drop it into a pot of boiling water, the frog will jump out immediately, knowing instinctively that if it stays in the pot, it will die. If you take a frog, however, and put it in a pot of cold water, and slowly, slowly, heat it to boiling, the frog will boil to death because it will fail to recognise the moment when it no longer has the energy to jump out of the pot; by the time it realises it's dying, it has lost its strength. It's called "learned helplessness". When your power or your voice has been taken away for a long time, you get used to that, and you fail to see the options that are available to you. You have a toddler, and you may be under the impression that staying in the marriage is best for the child. In my experience, and what research backs up, is that children first and foremost need a safe environment and parents who are happy. You are likely underestimating the effects on your child of living in a home with woman abuse. This is a complex picture, and if you were my client, I would want to get you to a stronger place emotionally where you're seeing the situation clearly and gathering resources and supports before you make any big decisions, but I do see that there are decisions that are there for you to make that can lead to a happy life for you and your child. I sincerely hope you seek professional help, with either a shelter for abused women or a therapist. I wish you the best. </s>

completely normal to feel lost, sad, and unwanted when your partner is away a lot, especially if it's a change from their usual behavior. It's important to remember that your feelings are valid and that you deserve to be in a relationship where you feel loved and supported.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that this new situation is causing you distress and that it's okay to feel that way. It's natural to feel upset when your partner is away a lot, especially if you're not used to it. It's important to communicate your feelings with your partner in a non-accusatory way. Try to have an open and honest conversation with him about how you're feeling and why.
In addition to talking to your partner, there are a few things you can do to help cope with the situation:
1. Take care of yourself: Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and exercising regularly. Taking care of your physical health can help improve your mental well-being.
2. Stay connected: Even though your partner is away, you can still stay connected through phone calls, video calls, or messaging. This can help you feel more connected to each other and can provide a sense of comfort.
3. Find ways to occupy yourself: Engage in hobbies, read a book, watch a movie, or take a class. Finding activities that you enjoy can help distract you from the feeling of loneliness and give you a sense of purpose.
4. Seek support: Reach out to friends and family for support. Talking to someone who understands can help you feel less alone and provide a different perspective on things.
5. Consider couples therapy: If you're finding it difficult to cope with your partner's absence on your own, consider seeking the help of a couples therapist. A therapist can provide a safe and neutral space for you to talk about your feelings and work on strategies to cope with the situation together.
Remember, it's okay to feel upset when your partner is away a lot. It's important to communicate your feelings with your partner and seek support from friends, family, or a therapist. With time and effort, you can work through this challenging situation and find ways to feel more connected and supported.

Response: Assuming there are no medical explanations for this issue, many men I've worked with on this come to see it as essentially a form of Anxiety. There is a phenomenon called the Yerkes Dodson Law (see below; source: Wikipedia), which basically states that if we feel either too much or too little stress, pressure, or nervousness about a task, it will adversely impact our ability to do carry it out successfully. The ideal amount of stress/arousal is right in the middle - not too little and not too much. This applies to more things than we might often realize - from giving a presentation, to ordering food, to making a free throw, to driving, to sexual intimacy as in this case. A common suggestion that many men find helpful is initiating open and honest conversations with their partners about this issue, and for a temporary period of time, agreeing to physical intimacy and sexual pleasure in other forms, and without the expectation of intercourse. There are many ways to go about that (which are outside the scope of this blog article), but this can be a path to connecting intimately and renewing physical bonding without unhelpful anxiety - and over time, can lead back to intimacy in all the ways that have become elusive. Best of luck. </s>
Output:
completely normal to experience fluctuations in sexual desire and performance, especially as men age. It's important to remember that erectile dysfunction (ED) is a common and treatable condition. There are many potential causes of ED, including physical, psychological, and lifestyle factors. Here are some possible causes of your symptoms:
1. Physical causes: ED can be caused by a variety of physical factors, such as heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, and prostate surgery. These conditions can reduce blood flow to the penis, making it difficult to achieve and maintain an erection.
2. Psychological causes: Psychological factors such as stress, anxiety, and relationship issues can also contribute to ED. These issues can lead to emotional distress, which can in turn affect sexual desire and performance.
3. Lifestyle causes: Lifestyle factors such as smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and lack of exercise can also contribute to ED. These factors can reduce blood flow to the penis and lead to decreased sexual function.

It's important to consult with a healthcare professional to rule out any underlying medical conditions that may be contributing to your symptoms. In the meantime, there are some things you can try to help improve your sexual function:

1. Communication: Communication is key in any relationship. Talk to your partner about your symptoms and how they are affecting you. Be open and honest about your feelings, and listen to your partner's perspective as well.

2. Exercise: Regular exercise can improve blood flow throughout the body, including the penis. This can help improve sexual function and overall health.

3. Stress reduction: Stress can exacerbate ED symptoms. Find healthy ways to manage stress, such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga.

4. Sleep: Getting enough sleep is important for overall health and well-being, including sexual function. Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep per night.

5. Sexual activity: Engaging in sexual activity can help improve sexual function. However, it's important to avoid pushing yourself too hard or engaging in activities that cause discomfort or pain.


It's important to remember that ED is a common and treatable condition. With patience, communication, and the right treatment, it is possible to improve sexual function and strengthen your relationship with your partner.

great that you're taking steps towards seeking therapy! Finding the right therapist can be a crucial factor in achieving successful treatment outcomes. Here are some signs that you may have found the right therapist for you:
1. **Comfort and trust**: You feel comfortable and at ease with your therapist, and you trust them to keep your confidences.
2. **Good communication**: Your therapist listens actively, asks thoughtful questions, and communicates in a way that makes sense to you.
3. **Personal compatibility**: You feel like you connect with your therapist on a personal level, and you enjoy their company.
4. **Therapy goals alignment**: Your therapist understands and supports your treatment goals, and they help you develop a plan to achieve them.
5. **Therapy style alignment**: You feel like your therapist's therapeutic approach aligns with your preferences and needs.

As for "training" your therapist, it's important to remember that therapy is a collaborative process between you and your therapist. Here are some ways you can work together to ensure you get the most out of treatment:

1. **Be open and honest**: Share your thoughts, feelings, and experiences with your therapist, and be open to their feedback and guidance.
2. **Set goals and expectations**: Work with your therapist to identify your treatment goals and expectations, and regularly check in on progress.
3. **Ask questions**: Don't be afraid to ask your therapist questions about their approach, their experience, or anything else that's on your mind.
4. **Be consistent**: Attend therapy sessions regularly and on time, and make sure to give your therapist enough notice if you need to reschedule.
5. **Follow homework**: Your therapist may assign you homework or exercises to do between sessions. Make sure to follow through on these tasks to get the most out of treatment.

Remember, finding the right therapist and working together to achieve your treatment goals is a collaborative process. Be patient, open, and communicative, and you'll be well on your way to successful therapy.

Response: The are two ways that such anxiety can be dealt with. One is an attempt to replace maladaptive thinking by examining the distorted thinking and resetting the fight-or-flight response with more reasonable, accurate ones. As an example "I'm scared of spiders." But if you change the thinking from being scared to "I'm bigger than the spider," it allows the mind to reach a calmer state of mind. Mindfulness-based therapy can also help  focus on the bodily sensations that arise when you feel anxious. Instead of avoiding or withdrawing from these feelings, remain present and fully experience the symptoms of anxiety. Instead of avoiding distressing thoughts, open up to them in an effort to realize and acknowledge that they are not literally true.Although it may seem counter-intuitive, fully realizing the experience of anxiety enables the release of over identification with negative thoughts. You can practice responding to disruptive thoughts, and letting these thoughts go.By remaining present in the body, you'll learn that the anxiety being experienced is merely a reaction to perceived threats. By positively responding to threatening events instead of being reactive you can overcome an erroneous fight-or-flight response. </s>

completely normal to feel anxious at times, especially when it seems like everything is dependent on you. It can be overwhelming to feel like you're alone in managing everything, and it's understandable that you might feel scared of the outcomes.
Firstly, it's important to recognize that you're not alone in this feeling. Many people struggle with anxiety, and it's okay to feel this way. It's important to acknowledge and validate your feelings, rather than trying to push them away or ignore them.
One thing that might help is to take things one step at a time. Instead of feeling overwhelmed by the big picture, try breaking things down into smaller, more manageable tasks. This can help you feel more in control and less anxious about the outcome. For example, if you're feeling anxious about a big project at work, try breaking it down into smaller tasks like researching, outlining, and drafting.
Another thing that might help is to practice self-care. This can look different for everyone, but some common self-care activities include exercise, meditation, spending time with loved ones, and engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy. Taking care of yourself can help you feel more grounded and less anxious.
It's also important to remember that you don't have to do everything by yourself. It's okay to ask for help when you need it, whether that's from friends, family, or a mental health professional. Reaching out for support can be incredibly empowering and can help you feel less alone in your anxiety.

Response: There is no scientifically established formula for understanding dreams, that I know about, however, many people get a great deal of value from exploring what their dreams mean. It is believed by many that our dreams contain metaphors that represent meaningful patterns in our lives and relationships and if we pay attention to them we can learn important things about ourselves. One thing you might try, to see if you can get more insight into the dream and possibly begin remembering things, is to take note of whatever you do remember, any details about your experience, such as when do you wake up from the dream, how do you feel, both emotionally and physically, what are you thinking about when you wake up, is there any pattern in terms of what happens to you in your waking life around the time you have this dream... If you can keep a journal or a recording device to speak into by your bed, you can try to record whatever you do remember and notice as soon as you wake up. People seem to have more difficulty remembering dreams, the more time they let go by before attempting to record the dream, or if you go back to sleep before recording what you remember. </s>

completely normal to have recurring dreams, and it's not uncommon for them to be vivid and emotional. It's possible that the dream you're having is a reflection of something in your waking life, or it could be a sign of something deeper going on in your subconscious.

1. Keep a dream journal: Writing down your dreams as soon as you wake up can help you remember them more clearly. Try keeping a notebook and pen next to your bed so you can jot down any dreams you have as soon as you wake up.
2. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness practices such as meditation or deep breathing can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions, including your dreams. This can help you become more aware of your dreams and remember them more clearly.
3. Try lucid dreaming: Lucid dreaming is the ability to become aware that you're dreaming while you're still asleep. This can allow you to take control of your dreams and explore your subconscious mind. There are several techniques you can try to help you have lucid dreams, such as repeating the phrase "I am dreaming" to yourself before you fall asleep, or using visualization techniques to help you become aware that you're dreaming.
4. Seek support: Talking to a trusted friend or family member about your dreams can help you process and understand them better. You could also consider seeking the help of a therapist or counselor who can help you explore the underlying causes of your dreams.

With time and practice, you may find that you're able to remember your dreams more clearly and gain a deeper understanding of your subconscious mind.

You won't have to "train" your therapist to give you what you need. Through open dialogue and feedback you and your therapist, together, can determine what works best for you. But do remember that being able to trust your therapist to guide and support you is key. So if you're having a hard time connecting with your therapist after 3-4 sessions, you will want to bring it up to them so you can discuss any barriers and if needed, request a referral for another therapist. </s>
Output:
completely normal to have questions and doubts about finding the right therapist and training them to provide the right support. Here are some things to consider when evaluating a therapist and how to communicate your needs effectively:
1. Credentials and Experience: Make sure the therapist has the necessary education, training, and experience in the areas you need help with. You can check their credentials on the therapist's website, professional organizations, or insurance provider.
2. Comfort and Trust: It's essential to feel comfortable and trust your therapist. Consider their communication style, personality, and approach to therapy. Do you feel heard and understood? Do you feel like they "get" you?
3. Personal Connection: A personal connection can help you open up and feel more comfortable sharing your thoughts and feelings. Consider the therapist's cultural background, gender identity, and age. Do these factors align with your preferences?
4. Specialization: Look for a therapist who specializes in the area you need help with, such as anxiety, depression, trauma, or relationships.
5. Availability and Location: Ensure the therapist has availability at times that work for you and is located in a convenient location.
6. Cost and Insurance: Check if the therapist accepts your insurance plan and what the cost is. Some therapists may offer sliding scale fees or accept payment plans.
7. Communication: Consider how well the therapist communicates with you. Do they explain things clearly? Do they listen actively? Do they respond promptly to your messages or calls?

To "train" your therapist, it's important to communicate your needs and expectations effectively. Here are some tips:

1. Be Clear and Direct: Share your goals and expectations directly and clearly with your therapist. Avoid beating around the bush or being vague.
2. Use "I" Statements: Express your thoughts and feelings using "I" statements. This helps your therapist understand your perspective and avoid getting defensive.
3. Set Boundaries: If there are certain topics or behaviors you don't want to discuss, let your therapist know. It's important to set boundaries and maintain a comfortable and safe space.
4. Provide Feedback: If you feel like your therapist isn't meeting your needs, communicate your concerns in a respectful and constructive manner. Offer specific examples and suggestions for improvement.
5. Be an Active Participant: Take an active role in your therapy sessions. Share your thoughts, feelings, and experiences, and work with your therapist to develop strategies and goals that are tailored to your needs.
Remember, finding the right therapist and communicating your needs effectively takes time and effort. Be patient, persistent, and open to exploring different options until you find the right fit.

From a behavioral standpoint you should refrain from punishing your son.  Instead of utilizing punishment when he wets himself provide contingencies prior to any accidents.  Sit down with your son and discuss the importance of utilizing the bathroom and responsibilities and inform him that if he chooses to wet his pants that his video games will not be available for use for him the next day(or your designated realistic time frame).  This way if an accident occurs, no heated words have to be exchanged because you have already laid the ground work.  Also allow him to clean up himself.  Gather cleaning supplies and and oversee cleaning operations without ridicule or negative feedback.  Since you have stated that you have an adolescent who is experiencing enuresis, you may want to check with your PCP and a licensed professional for underlying diagnosis that can be treated.   You can also call a local behavioral analyst. </s>
Output:
completely normal for children to experience accidents like peeing their pants, especially during times of intense focus or excitement. It's important to approach this issue with empathy and understanding, rather than punishment or blame. Here are some counseling points to help your son understand and manage this issue:
1. Validate his feelings: It's okay to feel upset or frustrated when this happens, but it's important to acknowledge and validate his feelings. Let him know that it's okay to feel upset and that you're there to support him.
2. Explain the situation: Use simple language to explain why this is happening. For example, you could say, "Sometimes when we're really focused on something, like a video game or movie, our bodies can't tell the difference between the game and our bladder. It's like our body gets mixed up and doesn't know what to do."
3. Offer solutions: Help him come up with solutions to prevent accidents. For example, he could carry a small change of clothes in his backpack, or you could set reminders for him to take breaks and go to the bathroom.
4. Practice bladder training: Bladder training can help him learn to control his bladder better. You could try doing small exercises together, like taking a few sips of water and then stopping, or going to the bathroom at set times during the day.
5. Encourage communication: Encourage him to communicate with you or a trusted adult when he needs to go to the bathroom. This can help him learn to express his needs and wants better, and can also help prevent accidents.
6. Be patient and consistent: Accidents can happen, but with patience and consistency, he can learn to manage them better. Try to stay calm and patient when accidents do happen, and consistently reinforce the importance of using the bathroom when needed.
7. Offer positive reinforcement: Praise him when he does use the bathroom correctly or when he shows good effort in managing his bladder. Positive reinforcement can help encourage him to continue making progress.
8. Seek professional help: If accidents persist and are causing significant distress or disruption to daily life, it may be helpful to seek the advice of a pediatrician or a specialist in bladder training. They can offer additional guidance and support to help your son manage this issue.
Remember, accidents like peeing his pants are not a reflection of his character or worth. With patience, consistency, and support, he can learn to manage this issue and feel confident and comfortable in his own skin.

Response:
Hello, and thank you for your question. You are clearly a
resourceful young person to reach out like this to find help. Good for you. I
have a few ideas and perhaps some other counselors will add some thoughts, too.

First, good for you for taking care of yourself and making
really good decisions – such as not getting into the car with dad when he is
intoxicated. It is really important that you consider your safety above all
else. 
To answer your heading question, yes, it is quite common for
people to blame themselves for other people’s actions. There are various
reasons why we do this. For one thing, someone may tell us that their behaviors are our fault. And depending on things like our relationship to that
person, past experiences, and our self-esteem, we may actually start to believe
it. What is important to remember is that your parents have the responsibility
to be sure that you are safe and
cared for, not the other way around. 
As for the other things you mentioned, I am concerned about both
your physical and emotional safety and well-being. It sounds like your father
has an alcohol abuse problem, and living with someone who is struggling with
addiction can be hard for anyone, let alone a teenager who is also trying to
deal with things like school. 
You may want to see if your school has a counselor or
someone you can talk to about what is going on. I will tell you that in some
states, what you have told me may be something that a counselor would have to
report to child protection services, but not necessarily. If you are concerned
about that, ask the counselor what they are obligated to report. 
If you don’t know a counselor, think about any other adult
that you would feel comfortable talking to. They may have some ideas. 
Sometimes individual states have non-profit chat lines or
hotlines for teens to call if they are struggling with things. You may be able
to find something like that in your state. I do warn your about doing random
searches, not every website is good, so be careful. 
This is clearly a tough spot for you to be in, so one of the
things that I encourage you to do while searching for support is to focus on
taking care of yourself. Sometimes things like this can really bring us down and
we stop doing the things we enjoy. Try really hard not to let that happen. If
you have interests, do them. If you catch yourself thinking too hard about
things, try to find something fun to do to distract yourself. Try to take care
of yourself in other ways, such as eating well. Exercise can really help when
we get stressed. 
I hope some of this was helpful. Good luck.
 
Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC </s>
Output:

Response:
<s> <<SYS>> Respond accordingly to the provided context. Try to give adequate counseling to the user. Show empathetic responses and naturality when answering. <</SYS>> [INST] How do you know you have the right therapist for you?
 Hello and thanks for your question! It's important to have the right therapist. I encourage you to start by checking out the website of the therapist. Their blog articles will reflect the kind of work they do and the approach they may take while working with you. If there's an email listed, go ahead and reach out. Ask the particular questions that are on your mind. Share a little of what you are looking for in a therapist. Are you a goal-direct, solution-focused individual who is looking for someone to listen and ask questions? Are you less self-directive and desire a therapist who can give you the consistent push to move forward? Are you interested in intertwining certain theory approaches? Maybe a cognitive-base or experiential? Art therapy or engaging in exercise while talking? Your therapist is out there. It's OK to try out a therapist for a session or two. Interview them as they interview you. It's also OK to change therapists; ask your present therapist for a referral. He or she should be willing to provide you with names of other providers and there's no shame in asking for it. You deserve to work with someone who fits your style!I imagine there's already enough things happening in your life if you are searching for a therapist. Do you really want to "train" your therapist? After all, you are paying them for their knowledge and expertise. It does take time to develop a relationship and developing one with your therapist is vital to your growth and satisfaction. Participating in therapy, for the most part, should be a time you anticipate and not avoid. Can you be honest with them? Are you trusting of the confidentiality they provide? Has this person clearly shared with you the limits of confidentiality if using insurance versus paying privately? Is there any part of you that "just isn't sure"? It's okay to assert yourself in therapy. As a therapist, I invite you to assert yourself as it's a way to develop self-confidence and resiliency. Not everyone thrives in therapy by sitting in an office or lounging on a couch. Some folks benefit by challenging themselves in various environments, or are more comfortable in their homes, online, in the community, at a retreat, etc. Give yourself a gift of spending some time finding the person that can work with you towards what you are searching. Although there's the convenience of the local non-profit agency in your area, it may not be what you need. Also, limiting yourself to the names of providers listed on your insurance may not lead to the "right one". There are many forms of therapy that insurances refuse to cover. When this happens, many times you can be reimbursed for your expenses by your insurance or you can use a Health Savings Card or Flexible Spending Card, there are many, many options. Therapy is about exploring yourself. Go ahead and feel free!If you feel as if you need to "train" your therapist, it seems that person is not the right fit for you. Engaging in treatment should be quite comfortable from the outset of treatment. Many independent practitioners or small group providers offer a free consultation to start the relationship. Perhaps that's a place for you to begin? Good luck and I wish you well! </s>
Output:
important to find a therapist who is a good fit for you and your needs. Here are some signs that you may have found the right therapist:
1. You feel comfortable and trust them: You should feel at ease sharing personal information and feelings with your therapist. You should also feel confident that they will keep your information private and secure.
2. They listen actively: A good therapist will actively listen to you, ask questions to clarify your thoughts and feelings, and respond in a non-judgmental manner.
3. They are empathetic: A good therapist will be able to understand and validate your emotions, even if they have not experienced the same thing themselves.
4. They tailor their approach to your needs: A good therapist will work with you to develop a treatment plan that is tailored to your specific needs and goals.
5. They are knowledgeable and up-to-date: A good therapist will have a strong understanding of the latest research and best practices in their field, and will be able to apply this knowledge in their work with you.
As for "training" your therapist, it is important to remember that therapy is a collaborative process between you and your therapist. Here are some ways you can work with your therapist to ensure that you get the most out of your treatment:
1. Be open and honest: It is important to be open and honest with your therapist about your thoughts, feelings, and experiences. This will help them understand you better and develop a treatment plan that is tailored to your needs.
2. Set goals and expectations: Work with your therapist to set specific goals for your treatment, and be clear about what you hope to achieve.
3. Ask questions: Don't be afraid to ask questions or seek clarification on any aspect of your treatment.
4. Be consistent: Consistency is key when it comes to therapy. Try to attend sessions regularly and follow through on any homework or exercises that are assigned.
5. Evaluate progress: Regularly evaluate your progress with your therapist and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
Remember, therapy is a collaborative process between you and your therapist. It is important to work together to ensure that you get the most out of your treatment.

Output:
completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and anxious when you're experiencing a difficult time. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this feeling, and that many people have gone through similar struggles.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your feelings are valid and real. It's okay to feel scared, helpless, or hopeless when things aren't going well. These feelings are a normal response to challenging situations, and they don't define your worth as a person.
It's great that you're reaching out for support. Talking to someone about how you're feeling can be really helpful in finding ways to cope with your anxiety. Have you considered talking to a therapist or counselor? They can provide you with a safe and non-judgmental space to talk about your feelings and work through them.
In the meantime, here are some things that might help you feel a bit better:
1. Practice deep breathing exercises: When we're feeling anxious, our breathing can become shallow and rapid. Taking a few moments to focus on deep, slow breaths can help calm the body and mind.
2. Engage in physical activity: Exercise can help reduce anxiety by releasing endorphins, which are natural mood-boosters. Even a short walk or some light stretching can help.
3. Try progressive muscle relaxation: This involves tensing and relaxing different muscle groups in your body. Start with your toes and work your way up to your head. As you tense each muscle group, hold for a few seconds, and then release.
4. Use positive self-talk: When we're feeling anxious, it can be easy to get caught up in negative thoughts. Try using positive affirmations to counteract these thoughts. For example, you could say to yourself, "I am strong and capable of handling this situation."
5. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment, without judgment. Try paying attention to your breath, your body, or your surroundings without getting caught up in thoughts or worries.
Remember, it's okay to feel overwhelmed and anxious sometimes. It's important to be kind to yourself and to reach out for support when you need it. Things might not feel better right away, but with time and effort, you can learn to manage your anxiety and feel more like yourself again.
Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other ways you'd like to try coping with your anxiety?

completely normal to feel a sense of dissatisfaction or discontentment with your current situation at times, especially when life gets in the way. However, it's important to remember that finding contentment and happiness is a journey that requires effort and dedication. Here are some strategies that may help you find contentment on a daily basis:
1. Practice gratitude: Take time each day to reflect on the things you are grateful for. This can help shift your focus away from negative thoughts and cultivate a more positive mindset.
2. Set realistic expectations: Be realistic about what you can achieve and what is within your control. Unrealistic expectations can lead to disappointment and discontentment.
3. Find activities that bring you joy: Engage in activities that make you happy and give you a sense of purpose. This could be anything from hobbies, exercise, or spending time with loved ones.
4. Cultivate mindfulness: Practice mindfulness meditation or other mindfulness techniques to help you stay present and focused on the current moment. This can help reduce stress and anxiety, which can contribute to discontentment.
5. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a therapist for support when you're feeling discontent. Talking through your feelings with someone who cares about you can help you gain perspective and find ways to improve your situation.
6. Take care of yourself: Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and taking time to relax and recharge. When you feel physically well, you're more likely to feel mentally well too.
7. Find ways to give back: Helping others can give you a sense of purpose and fulfillment. Look for ways to volunteer or give back to your community, whether it's through a local charity or simply by being a good friend and neighbor.
8. Practice self-compassion: Be kind to yourself when you're feeling discontent. Remember that everyone experiences ups and downs, and it's okay to not be okay all the time. Treat yourself with the same kindness and compassion that you would offer to a friend.
9. Seek professional help: If you're struggling with persistent feelings of discontentment or depression, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with the tools and support you need to manage your feelings and improve your overall well-being.
Remember, finding contentment is a journey that takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself, and don't be afraid to reach out for support when you need it. With time and practice, you can cultivate a more content and fulfilling life.

Hello there! 😊 I completely understand how you feel. It's normal to feel stressed and less confident when you have to give presentations, especially when it's part of a graduate program. Remember, everyone feels this way at some point, and it's okay to feel nervous. 🌟
Here are a few things that might help you build your confidence: 💪
1️⃣ Practice, practice, practice! The more you practice, the more comfortable you'll feel with the material and the presentation itself. Try practicing in front of a mirror, a friend, or family member. 💬
2️⃣ Take deep breaths and try to relax. Before you give your presentation, take a few deep breaths and focus on your breathing. This can help calm your nerves and reduce your stress levels. 😌
3️⃣ Focus on your message, not your nervousness. Instead of worrying about how you're coming across, focus on the message you're trying to convey. Remember, you're speaking to share information and ideas, not to impress anyone with your public speaking skills. 📢
4️⃣ Visualize success. Imagine yourself giving a great presentation and receiving positive feedback. See yourself feeling confident and in control. 🔥
5️⃣ Speak slowly and clearly. When you're nervous, it's easy to speak too quickly or mumble. Try to slow down and enunciate your words. This will help you feel more in control and make it easier for your audience to understand you. 💬
Remember, building confidence takes time and practice. Be patient with yourself and keep working at it. You got this! 💪
I hope these tips help you feel more confident and in control when giving presentations. Remember, you're not alone in this feeling, and with time and practice, you'll become a pro at public speaking! 💪
Now, go out there and slay that presentation! 💥

completely normal to have questions and concerns about life after death, especially if you were raised in a religion that places a strong emphasis on the idea of an afterlife. It's natural to feel overwhelmed or anxious when thinking about the prospect of living forever, as it can be a difficult concept to wrap your head around.
Firstly, it's important to recognize that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with similar thoughts and feelings, and it's okay to feel this way. It's important to be kind to yourself and to try to approach these thoughts with compassion and understanding.
One way to think about this is to consider the idea that life after death might not be exactly what we expect it to be. While some religions teach that there is a clear division between heaven and hell, others offer more nuanced understandings of the afterlife. For example, some belief systems view the afterlife as a place of transition and growth, where individuals can learn and evolve beyond the limitations of their physical bodies.
Another perspective is to consider the idea that death is not an end, but rather a transition to a new chapter in our journey. This can be a comforting thought, as it suggests that our lives are not limited to the time we spend in this physical world.
It's also worth noting that many people find comfort and meaning in the idea of an afterlife, as it can provide a sense of hope and purpose in the face of death. While it's understandable that you might feel overwhelmed by this concept, it's important to remember that it can also be a source of solace and strength.
Ultimately, the way you feel about the idea of living forever is okay. It's normal to have mixed feelings about something as profound and complex as death and the afterlife. What's important is to be kind to yourself and to seek out support from loved ones, or a mental health professional if you're struggling to cope with these thoughts.
Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Reach out to those around you, or seek out professional help if you need it. And always remember that it's okay to feel the way you do.

Output:
understandable that you're feeling frustrated and concerned about your son's behavior, especially after he had shown some positive changes. It's important to remember that adolescence can be a challenging time for young people as they navigate their identity, independence, and responsibilities.
Firstly, it's essential to acknowledge that your son is going through a difficult phase, and it's not uncommon for teenagers to struggle with motivation and responsibility. It's important to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, rather than resorting to punitive measures.
Here are some suggestions for how you can help your son:
1. Have an open and honest conversation: Sit down with your son and have an open and honest conversation about his behavior. Listen to his perspective and express your concerns in a non-judgmental way. Try to understand what may be causing his lack of motivation and help him identify ways to address these issues.
2. Offer support and guidance: Let your son know that you're there to support him and offer guidance, but also be clear about your expectations for his behavior. Encourage him to take responsibility for his actions and help him develop a plan to get back on track.
3. Set clear boundaries and consequences: It's important to set clear boundaries and consequences for your son's behavior. Make sure he understands what is expected of him and what the consequences will be if he doesn't meet those expectations.
4. Encourage self-reflection: Encourage your son to reflect on his behavior and identify areas where he can improve. Help him develop a growth mindset and encourage him to take ownership of his actions.
5. Seek professional help: If your son's behavior persists and you're concerned about his well-being, consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor. They can provide additional support and guidance to help your son navigate this challenging time.

In summary, it's important to approach this situation with empathy, understanding, and a willingness to listen and offer support. By working together with your son, you can help him develop the skills and habits he needs to become a responsible and independent young adult.

Response: Being a parent can be all-consuming.  And there are more societal pressures on mothers to be everything to their children and families.  In that effort to be everything (cook, housekeeper, planner, social organizer, teacher, etc) it can be easy to forget about being you.  We can certainly acknowledge that becoming a mother likely means giving up or sacrificing parts of yourself for motherhood.  There are parts of becoming a mother that can be wonderful and magical, and parts of it that can be just flat out hard.  I think it is very important however, for all parents to ask for what they need and to carve out the time to nurture their individuality.  This may not only be supportive to you, but it sets a great example for your kids about how to advocate for their needs, and teach them about the depth and interests of their mother. </s>
Output:
completely normal to feel lost and unsure of your identity, especially when you're in the midst of raising a family. It's easy to get caught up in the day-to-day responsibilities of motherhood and wifehood that you forget to take care of yourself and your own needs. It's important to remember that taking care of yourself and prioritizing your own happiness is not selfish – it's essential for being the best mother and partner you can be.

First of all, let me say that you're not alone in this feeling. Many women go through this same struggle, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed and unsure of who you are outside of your roles as mother and wife. It's important to remember that your identity is not solely defined by these roles. You are more than just a mom and a wife – you are a unique and valuable person with your own interests, hobbies, and passions.
One way to start reconnecting with your pre-motherhood identity is to make time for yourself and do things that bring you joy and fulfillment. This might be as simple as taking a relaxing bath, reading a book, or going for a walk by yourself. It might also involve pursuing hobbies or interests that you had before you became a mother – whether that's painting, writing, gardening, or anything else that brings you happiness.
Another important thing to remember is that it's okay to feel unhappy and trapped at times. It's normal to feel this way, especially when you're in the midst of raising a family. However, it's important to recognize when these feelings are becoming overwhelming and to seek support from your partner, friends, or a therapist. Talking through your feelings with someone who understands can be incredibly helpful in finding ways to cope with them.
Finally, remember that you don't have to have it all figured out right away. It's okay to take things one step at a time and to focus on self-care and self-discovery. You might find that as you prioritize your own happiness and well-being, you become a better mother and partner as a result.

In conclusion, it's important to remember that you are more than just a mom and a wife – you are a unique and valuable person with your own identity and interests. Making time for yourself, seeking support when needed, and focusing on self-care and self-discovery can help you reconnect with your pre-motherhood identity and find happiness and fulfillment in your life. Remember, you don't have to have it all figured out right away – just take things one step at a time and prioritize your own well-being.

Output:
